Description:
DESCRIPTION:THE WORK CONDUCTED USING THIS GRANT FUNDING WILL BE INSTRUMENTAL IN FURTHER STRENGTHENING AND ADVANCING THE WHITE MOUNTAIN APACHE TRIBE'S SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE A BASELINE WASTE AUDIT THAT IDENTIFIES THE ORIGIN, COMPOSITION, AND VOLUME OF SOLID WASTE GENERATED ACROSS THE RESERVATION. THIS BASELINE EVALUATION IS CRUCIAL TO PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT BECAUSE IT PROVIDES QUANTIFIED DATA AND INFORMATION FROM WHICH PROGRAM DECISIONS CAN BE MADE, GOALS CAN BE ESTABLISHED, AND RESOURCE REQUIREMENTS CAN BE IDENTIFIED AND ADDRESSED. THIS WILL ALLOW THE TRIBE TO CONTINUE TO DEVELOP ITS SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM IN A COHESIVE, STRATEGIC, AND LOGICAL MANNER AND IMPROVE SUCCESS FOR PROGRAM LONGEVITY. THIS GRANT WILL ASSIST THE TRIBE IN INITIATING A PROGRAM TO ALLOW THE SOLID WASTE PROGRAM TO BE CONDUCTED IN A MORE SUSTAINABLE MANNER, INCLUDING RECYCLING, DIVERSION, COMPOSTING, AND GHG EMISSIONS REDUCTIONS.

THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $100,000.  PRE-AWARD COSTS ARE APPROVED BACK TO 01/02/2023.ACTIVITIES:WITH THIS GRANT, THE WHITE MOUNTAIN APACHE TRIBE WILL COMPLETE FOUR ACTIVITIES: EVALUATE WASTE STREAM VOLUME AND COMPOSITION OF RESIDENTIAL AND COMMERCIAL SOURCES; IDENTIFY POTENTIAL WASTE DIVERSION, RECYCLING, OR COMPOSTING OPTIONS FOR WASTE STREAMS; INVENTORY ILLEGAL DUMPS AND QUANTIFY COMPOSITION; AND PREPARE A SUMMARY REPORT OF PROJECT FINDINGS WITH CONCLUSIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS FOR FUTURE ACTIVITIES.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES ASSISTANCE TO THE WHITE MOUNTAIN APACHE TRIBE TO BUILD ITS CAPACITY, MANAGE WASTE MORE SUSTAINABLY, AND PRESERVE RESOURCES. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT ARE THE MEMBERS AND/OR RESIDENTS OF THE WHITE MOUNTAIN APACHE TRIBE/RESERVATION.  DELIVERABLES INCLUDE RESULTS FROM RESIDENTIAL AND COMMERCIAL WASTE AUDITS, AUDIT FINDINGS OF ILLEGAL DUMPS, UPDATED INTEGRATED WASTE MANAGEMENT PLAN, AND A FINAL REPORT THAT PRESENTS THE FINDINGS OF THE PROJECT AND INCLUDES AN EVALUATION OF POTENTIAL SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT ALTERNATIVES SUCH AS RECYCLING, DIVERSION, AND/OR COMPOSTING AND IDENTIFY OPTIONS TO REDUCE SOLID WASTE DISPOSAL BY 25% BY 2025.

THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES ARE THAT THIS PROJECT WILL HAVE SIGNIFICANT POSITIVE IMPACTS TO OVERALL COMMUNITY HEALTH AND REDUCTION OF THREATS TO HUMAN HEALTH AND THE ENVIRONMENT. THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE A FIRST STEP IN UNDERSTANDING HOW TO BETTER MANAGE ILLEGALLY-DUMPED ELECTRONIC WASTES; HOUSEHOLD APPLIANCES; CLEANERS, PAINTS, AND SOLVENTS; AUTOMOTIVE WASTE, AND PESTICIDES AND HERBICIDES. THESE WASTES ARE KNOWN TO CONTRIBUTE TO TOXIC AND HAZARDOUS CHEMICAL RELEASES INTO THE SOIL AND EVENTUALLY INFILTRATE INTO GROUNDWATER OR BE RELEASED TO THE ATMOSPHERE. ADDITIONALLY, THE GRANT WILL BE USED TO ADDRESS THE IMMEDIATE AND CHRONIC THREATS TO THE TRIBE'S TOURISM AND RECREATION SECTORS THAT RESULT FROM INEFFECTIVE SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT. BY IDENTIFYING AND IMPLEMENTING OPPORTUNITIES FOR INCREASED RECYCLING AND WASTE DIVERSION, THE WASTE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM CAN BE MORE COST EFFECTIVE. OPEN DUMPS AND UNCOLLECTED HOUSEHOLD GARBAGE AND BULK MATERIALS STAIN THE IMAGE AND BEAUTY OF THE FORESTS AND WATERS THAT DRAW VISITORS TO THE WHITE MOUNTAINS. AS A RESULT, THE LAND BECOMES LESS ATTRACTIVE TO POTENTIAL VISITORS AND THEIR ASSOCIATED TOURISM EXPENDITURES THAT ARE SO VITAL TO THE TRIBE. THIS GRANT WILL HELP ELIMINATE THIS THREAT TO TRIBE EARNINGS.

DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP NEW ANAEROBIC DIGESTION (AD) CAPACITY FOR PROCESSING FOOD WASTE AND TO DEMONSTRATE THE FEASIBILITY OF SMALL-SCALE AD SYSTEMS IN RURAL COMMUNITIES. THE RECIPIENT PLANS TO ESTABLISH A PILOT ANAEROBIC DIGESTION FACILITY ON TRIBAL LAND TO DIVERT THE FOOD WASTE GENERATED ON ADJACENT TO ITS LAND, BEGINNING WITH AN ELEMENTARY SCHOOL. DIGESTATE AND BIOGAS PRODUCT WILL BE UTILIZED TO SUPPORT FOOD SOVEREIGNTY BY EFFORTS ADDING NUTRIENTS TO THE SOIL AND POWERING THE WELL WATERING SYSTEM IN FOOD PRODUCTION SPACES. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE;  GATHERING INFORMATION FOR PROGRAM DIRECTION AND INSTALL THE ANAEROBIC DIGESTOR FACILITY, CREATING FOOD WASTE COLLECTION SERVICE FOR A LIMITED AREA OF THE RESERVATION, WHILE CREATING TARGETED EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS TO ENCOURAGE FOOD WASTE DIVERSION FOR PROGRAM EXPANSION, AND DEMONSTRATING REPLICABLE SUCCESSES OF THE ANAEROBIC DIGESTOR PROGRAM.  THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $200,000.  PREAWARD COSTS HAVE BEEN APPROVED BACK TO 4/1/22.  SEE TERMS AND CONDITIONS.ACTIVITIES:.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:.

DESCRIPTION:THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $169,054. PRE-AWARD COSTS HAVE BEEN APPROVED BACK TO 06/01/2022.

THIS PROJECT IS A STUDY THAT WILL EVALUATE THE CONVERSION OF EXISTING ANAEROBIC DIGESTERS AT MONTEREY ONE WATER'S (M1W) WASTEWATER TREATMENT FACILITY TO CO-DIGEST SEWAGE SLUDGE WITH FOOD AND OTHER ORGANIC WASTES DIVERTED FROM MONTEREY REGIONAL WASTE MANAGEMENT DISTRICT (MRWMD). THE OBJECTIVE OF THE STUDY IS TO IDENTIFY STRATEGIES FOR USING FOOD WASTE AND ORGANIC MATERIALS TO A) OPTIMIZE UN-USED ASSETS TO INCREASE THE USE OF ANAEROBIC DIGESTION; B) EXPAND BIOGAS GENERATION FOR PRODUCTIVE USE; AND C) SUPPORT FEDERAL AND STATE INITIATIVES TO CREATE A CLEANER, SAFER ENVIRONMENT. ACTIVITIES:
1) QUANTIFICATION AND CHARACTERIZATION OF FOOD WASTE IN THE PROJECT AREA.
2) CONDUCT AN ASSESSMENT OF THE FACILITY'S EXISTING ORGANICS PROCESSING TECHNOLOGIES AND INFRASTRUCTURE, AS WELL AS CURRENT AND FUTURE ENERGY DEMANDS.
3) DEFINE OPPORTUNITIES AND CONSTRAINTS TO MAXIMIZE UN-USED CAPACITY FOR CO-DIGESTION.
4) DETERMINE SUITABLE TECHNOLOGIES FOR THE PRE-PROCESSING OF FEEDSTOCK AND CO-DIGESTION.
5) PRODUCE A FINAL FEASIBILITY STUDY WHICH MEETS THE PROJECT OBJECTIVES AND QUANTIFIES THE ANTICIPATED ENVIRONMENTAL BENEFITS.

UC DAVIS WILL DEMONSTRATE A SYSTEM FOR BIOMASS RECYCLING AND CREATION OF AMMONIA FERTILIZER TO OPTIMIZE THEIR CURRENT DIGESTER SYSTEM AND DISSEMINATE RESULTS.  IT ADDRESSES EPA'S SEARCH FOR PROPOSALS TO INCREASE THE UTILIZATION OF ANAEROBIC DIGESTION TECHNOLOGY FOR A WIDE VARIETY OF FEEDSTOCKS AT MANY TYPES OF FACILITIES. IT ALSO ADDRESSES THE SEARCH FOR INCREASED USE OF INNOVATIVE INFRASTRUCTURE (RNG CONVERSION AND PIPELINE INJECTION) IN THE AD INDUSTRY.  IT WILL BENEFIT THE COMMUNITY BY ACCEPTING FOOD WASTE AND BY TESTING A NEW AGRICULTURAL FERTILIZER THAT COULD BENEFIT CROPS. THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $299,627. PREAWARD COSTS ARE APPROVED BACK TO 2/1/2021. THE FEDERAL SHARE FOR THIS AGREEMENT IS 100% OF THE TOTAL PROJECT COST, NOT TO EXCEED THE ASSISTANCE AMOUNT OF $299,627. NOTE THAT THE HEADER OF THIS AWARD CAPTION INDICATES GRANT AGREEMENT WHEREAS THIS IS A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT (REFER TO PROGRAMMATIC TERMS AND CONDITIONS).

THE PROJECT WILL CONDUCT A FEASIBILITY EVALUATION OF THE CITY'S ORGANIC WASTE FOR ANAEROBIC DIGESTION AND TO TEST RUN DELIVERY TO THE CITY'S WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANT FOR CO-DIGESTION.  SPECIFICALLY, THE PROJECT WILL CONSIST OF TWO PARTS: PART I: PERFORM A FEASIBILITY EVALUATION FOR DIVERSION OF ORGANIC FOOD WASTE INTO THE CITY'S WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANT ANAEROBIC DIGESTER, AND PART II: PERFORM A BENCH SCALE STUDY TO VERIFY AND UPDATE THE FEASIBILITY EVALUATION FINDINGS. IT ADDRESSES EPA'S SEARCH FOR PROPOSALS TO INCREASE THE UTILIZATION OF ANAEROBIC DIGESTION TECHNOLOGY FOR A WIDE VARIETY OF FEEDSTOCKS AT MANY TYPES OF FACILITIES. IT ALSO ADDRESSES THE SEARCH FOR INCREASED USE OF INNOVATIVE INFRASTRUCTURE IN THE AD INDUSTRY. THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE COMMUNITY BE INCREASING THE CAPACITY TO DIVERT MORE FOOD WASTE FROM LANDFILLS AND INCINERATION, AND MAY REDUCE PUBLIC EXPENSES BY REDUCING THE AMOUNT OF FOOD WASTE CURRENTLY BEING SENT TO A PRIVATE COMPOSTER. THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $182,630.

DESCRIPTION:THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL UTILIZE A PARTNERSHIP WITH THE CITY OF MUSCATINE, IOWA TO STUDY ANAEROBIC DIGESTION AT THE MUSCATINE MUNICIPAL WATER RESOURCE RECOVERY FACILITY (WRRF). UTILIZING A SIGNIFICANTLY NEW COMBINATION OF SENSORS, REAL-TIME PROCESS ANALYZERS, DATA ANALYTICS AND MODELING, RESEARCHERS WILL EXAMINE THE BENEFITS AND TECHNOLOGICAL FEASIBILITY OF OPTIMIZING ANAEROBIC DIGESTION.  THE 'DIGITAL TWIN' APPROACH WILL ALLOW THE UNIVERSITY TO MAXIMIZE METHANE PRODUCTION AND MINIMIZE DIGESTER UPSETS BY WORKING WITH AN OPERATING MUNICIPAL DIGESTER. THE PROJECT QUALIFIES AS A DEMONSTRATION AS DEFINED BY SWDA   1004(2A), 42 USC 6903(2A).ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL: 1) EXPAND EXISTING AD CAPACITY FOR PROCESSING FOOD WASTE; 2) DEMONSTRATE A DIGITAL TWIN PROCESS MONITORING AND DECISION-MAKING APPROACH THAT WILL INCREASE AD FOOD WASTE UTILIZATION IN A REPLICABLE MANNER; AND 3) SUPPORT EFFORTS BY THE MUSCATINE COMMUNITY AND OTHER CITIES, INDUSTRIES, AND FARMS IN IOWA TO INCREASE FOOD WASTE DIVERSION RATES. MORE SPECIFICALLY, THE PROJECT WILL: 1) MAXIMIZE OPPORTUNITIES TO UTILIZE EXISTING, UN-USED CAPACITY FOR DIGESTION OR CO-DIGESTION; 2) PROMOTE OPERATIONAL INNOVATIONS TO AD SYSTEMS AND PROCESSES; 3) DEVELOP SOLUTIONS TO BARRIERS THAT PREVENT AD USE OR DEVELOPMENT; 4) PRESENT LOGISTICAL SOLUTIONS TO OPTIMIZE PROCESSING OF FEEDSTOCKS VIA AD; 5) INCREASE THE OVERALL AMOUNT OF FOOD WASTE OR OTHER ORGANIC WASTE BEING PROCESSED VIA AD; AND 6) REDUCE SULFUR EMISSIONS IN A SULFUR DIOXIDE NON-ATTAINMENT COMMUNITY.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:ANTICIPATED OUTPUTS AND OUTCOMES: PROJECT OUTPUTS INCLUDE: 1) OPTIMIZED DIVERSION OF UP TO 20 TONS OF FOOD SCRAPS AND/OR FOOD RESIDUALS PER DAY AT THE MUSCATINE WATER RESOURCE RECOVERY FACILITY; 2) TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO THE MUSCATINE WATER RESOURCE RECOVERY FACILITY; 3A) DIRECT ENGAGEMENT WITH THE CITIES OF DES MOINES AND SIOUX CITY REGARDING THE POTENTIAL APPLICATION OF THE DIGITAL TWIN APPROACH TO CO-DIGESTION OPERATIONS; 3B) DIRECT ENGAGEMENT WITH ON FARM DIGESTERS NEAR AMANA AND STOCKTON, IOWA, ON THE DIGITAL TWIN APPROACH TO IMPROVING ANAEROBIC DIGESTION PERFORMANCE; 4) ENGAGEMENT WITH 20 LARGE FOOD PRODUCTION FACILITIES AND GROCERS CURRENTLY PROVIDING HIGH STRENGTH ORGANICS TO ANAEROBIC DIGESTION FACILITIES IN IOWA; 5) EIGHT PLANNING AND OUTCOMES MEETINGS WITH, AND TWO COMMUNITY VISIONING AND REPORT-BACK MEETINGS FACILITATED BY, CLEAN AIR MUSCATINE; 6) ONE OUTCOMES AND FEASIBILITY REPORT TO THE IOWA WATER ENVIRONMENT ASSOCIATION, IOWA'S WATER ENVIRONMENT FEDERATION AFFILIATE; 7) ONE DIGITAL TWIN OF THE MUSCATINE WATER RESOURCE RECOVERY FACILITY.

MEASURABLE OUTCOMES INCLUDE: 1) INCREASED RESOURCES AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR THE MUSCATINE WATER RESOURCE RECOVERY FACILITY AND AT LEAST THREE OTHER FACILITIES IN IOWA; 2) ADVANCES IN ANAEROBIC DIGESTION OPERATIONAL DECISION-MAKING THROUGH THE CREATION AND USE OF A DIGITAL TWIN; 3) IMPROVED ABILITY OF KRAFT/HEINZ, NESTLEACUTE; PURINA, CONAGRA, WEST LIBERTY FOODS, HYVEE FOOD MARKETS, AND OTHER BUSINESSES TO USE THE EXISTING ANAEROBIC DIGESTION CAPACITY AT THE MUSCATINE WATER RESOURCE RECOVERY FACILITY; 4) RESEARCH TO INCREASE THE PERCENTAGE FOOD WASTE IN FEED STOCK FOR MUNICIPAL DIGESTERS; 5) AT LEAST A 5% REDUCTION OF HYDROGEN SULFIDE GAS PRODUCTION PER POUND OF VOLATILE SOLIDS LOADED TO THE ANAEROBIC DIGESTION; 6) AT LEAST A 5% INCREASE IN BIOMETHANE PRODUCTION WITHOUT AN INCREASED RISK OF ANAEROBIC DIGESTION UPSET; 7) COST SAVINGS OF ~$80,000 PER YEAR IN NATURAL GAS EXPENSE FOR WATER RESOURCE RECOVERY FACILITY BOILERS; 8) ALMOST ONE MILLION SCF OF BIOGAS USED RATHER THAN FLARED WITH A GROSS HEATING VALUE OF ~650 BTU PER SCF; 9) OVER 10M GALLONS OF BIOSOLIDS CONTAINING ~130,000 LBS. OF NITROGEN AND 40,000 LBS. OF PHOSPHORUS APPLIED TO 500 ACRES OF FARM LAND.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO CREATE AN ENVIRONMENTAL VIRTUAL LEARNING PROGRAM AND CURRICULUM FOR GRADES K-12 IN DES MOINES, IOWA, SCHOOL DISTRICTS AND OTHER EDUCATIONAL GROUPS TO LEARN ABOUT SUSTAINABLE REUSE AND RECYCLING AND PREVENTION OF TRASH AND LITTER USING GAMING EQUIPMENT. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE CREATION OF 360-DEGREE VIRTUAL GAMES, VIRTUAL TOURS, VIDEOS, AND OTHER MULTIMEDIA RESOURCES FOR STUDENTS TO TAKE VIRTUAL TOURS OF THE METRO PARK EAST LANDFILL, METRO HAZARDOUS WASTE DROP OFF, AND THE MATERIAL RECOVERY FACILITY IN DES MOINES; TRACKING OF EQUIPMENT USAGE; PROVIDING WASTE DIVERSION AND PREVENTION OF WASTE INFORMATION TAILORED TO EACH GRADE LEVEL; AND MEASUREMENT OF STUDENTS' KNOWLEDGE GAINED. DELIVERABLES INCLUDE TWO SETS OF 15 VIRTUAL GAMING EQUIPMENT FOR A TOTAL OF 30 GOGGLES, A PRETEST AND POSTTEST OF STUDENTS' KNOWLEDGE TO MEASURE WHAT THEY LEARNED ABOUT SUSTAINABILITY FROM THE VIRTUAL GAME CURRICULUM. OUTCOMES ARE CREATION OF AN ACCESSIBLE EDUCATION PROGRAM AND INCREAS

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO DEVELOP A REGIONAL FOOD WASTE REDUCTION ACTION PLAN, COLLABORATIVE FOOD SYSTEM MAPPING WEBSITE, AND FOOD EDUCATIONAL CAMPAIGN FOR THE KANSAS CITY REGION WHICH INCLUDES THE FOLLOWING BENEFICIARIES: CASS, CLAY, JACKSON, PLATTE, AND RAY COUNTIES IN MISSOURI, AND JOHNSON, LEAVENWORTH, MIAMI, AND WYANDOTTE COUNTIES IN KANSAS.  ACTIVITIES INCLUDE GLEANING, COMPOSTING, AND FOOD RECOVERY FROM WHOLESALE GROCERS; EDUCATING CONSUMERS AND FOOD WASTE GENERATORS ABOUT THE IMPACTS OF WASTE FOOD ON THE ENVIRONMENT, ECONOMY, AND COMMUNITY; CREATING TOOLS TO FACILITATE RESCUE OF FOOD TO CHARITABLE ORGANIZATIONS; AND CREATING A FOOD SYSTEM MAP AND WEBSITE.  DELIVERABLES INCLUDE RESULTS OF STAKEHOLDER WORKSHOPS, SOURCE REDUCTION PLAN, REGIONAL FOOD SYSTEM MAP, REGIONAL FOOD SYSTEM WEBSITE, AND EDUCATION CAMPAIGN AND MATERIALS.  OUTCOMES INCLUDE CONTINUOUS INFORMATION SHARING AND EXCHANGE AMONG THE STAKEHOLDER GROUPS; 150,000 TONS OF FOOD WASTE DIVERTED FROM THE REGION'S LAN

THE PURPOSE OF GRANT IS TO REDUCE FOOD AND PACKAGING WASTE, PREVENT TRASH AND LITTER AND PROVIDE TRAINING ON SUSTAINABLE PEST MANAGEMENT.  KANSAS STATE UNIVERSITY WILL PARTNER WITH JOHNSON COUNTY DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENT TO COMPLETE THE PROJECT.  THE BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE BLUE VALLEY SCHOOL DISTRICT, DE SOTO SCHOOL DISTRICT AND JOHNSON COUNTY COMMUNITY COLLEGE, INTERESTED INDUSTRIES, COMMUNITIES AND INSTITUTIONS IN JOHNSON COUNTY AND TARGETED SECTORS IN FOOD AND BEVERAGE MANUFACTURING, GROCERY STORES, CASINOS, HEALTHCARE,  AND AEROSPACE MANUFACTURING. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE WASTE AUDITS IN SCHOOLS, INDUSTRIES, COMMUNITIES, AND INSTITUTIONS TO PROMOTE SOURCE REDUCTION OPTIONS FOR MANAGING THEIR WASTE STREAMS, DEVELOP WASTE DIVERSION OPTIONS AT EACH SITE, AN INTERACTIVE STATEWIDE MAP OF EXISTING RECYCLING INFRASTRUCTURE, USE OF A LITTER REDUCTION APP, AND CREATE CASE STUDIES FOR EACH SECTOR TO SHARE WITH OTHER SECTORS STATEWIDE AND NATIONALLY. THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO EVALUATE THE FEASIBILITY OF A SUSTAINABLE ORGANIC MATERIALS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM TO COMPOST YARD WASTE, FOOD WASTE, AND BIOSOLIDS CURRENTLY LANDFILLED BY GOVERNMENT, RESIDENTS, AND BUSINESSES LOCATED IN WYANDOTTE COUNTY, KANSAS, WHO WILL BE THE BENEFICIARIES OF THE PROJECT.  ACTIVITIES INCLUDE A FEASIBILITY STUDY FOR AN ORGANIC MATERIALS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM, EVALUATION OF THREE COMPOSTING TECHNOLOGIES, MEETINGS WITH LARGE FOOD WASTE GENERATORS, ORGANIC MATERIAL PROCESSORS AND COMMUNITY LEADERS IN WYANDOTTE COUNTY AND REGION TO DETERMINE ANNUAL GENERATION QUANTITIES AND PROXIMITY TO ORGANIC FEEDSTOCKS, EVALUATION OF HYDROGEOLOGIC CONDITIONS AND SOLID WASTE PERMITTING REQUIREMENTS, COST ANALYSIS OF COMPOST FACILITY CONSTRUCTION, MAINTENANCE AND REGULATORY COMPLIANCE, THREE CONCEPTUAL DESIGN DRAWINGS FOR FACILITY LAYOUT, TRAFFIC FLOWS, CONTACT WATER AND STORMWATER MANAGEMENT, AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONTROLS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO REDUCE THE AMOUNT OF SINGLE USE PACKAGING IN ST. LOUIS MISSOURI AT 5 TO 10 RESTAURANTS WITH THE HELP OF GREEN DINING ALLIANCE OF ST. LOUIS, THE MISSOURI PRODUCT STEWARDSHIP COUNCIL, THE CITY OF ST. LOUIS, AND ST. LOUIS JEFFERSON SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT DISTRICT.  ACTIVITIES ARE TO DEVELOP A STATEWIDE SUSTAINABLE PACKAGING STAKEHOLDER WORKGROUP, MEASURE THE PLASTIC FOOTPRINT AND DEVELOP SOURCE REDUCTION PLANS FOR RESTAURANTS, PREPARE AND IMPLEMENT A PILOT REUSABLE CONTAINER PROGRAM, CREATE A MOBILE APP, DEVELOP A CITY WIDE FOOD SERVICEWARE SOURCE REDUCTION PLAN AND PROMOTE THE PLAN STATE WIDE AND NATIONALLY WITH A NATIONAL SOCIAL MEDIA CAMPAIGN AND WEBINAR IN SEVERAL LANGUAGES.  DELIVERABLES FOR THE PROJECT ARE A REUSABLE FOOD SERVICE WARE SOURCE REDUCTION PLAN FOR RESTAURANTS, CITY WIDE FOOD SERVICE SOURCE REDUCTION PLAN, SOURCE REDUCTION TOOLKIT AND PILOT CASE STUDIES, AND NATIONAL SOCIAL MEDIA CAMPAIGN AND WEBINAR. THE OUTCOMES ARE TO REDUCE THE NUMBER
PROMOTES USE OF INTEGRATED SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS.
IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY WILL CONDUCT A SUSTAINABILITY ASSESSMENT OF NEW METHODS FOR CONSTRUCTING AND MAINTAINING UNPAVED ROADS USING RECYCLED RATHER TH

MONTANA STATE UNIVERSITY PLANS TO ASSESS THE POTENTIAL OF ANAEROBIC DIGESTION OF FOOD SCRAPS AT THE HOUSEHOLD LEVEL TO PRODUCE BIOFERTILIZER. IN A PILOT STUDY IN TWELVE HOUSEHOLDS IN BOZEMAN, MT, THIS PROJECT WILL (1) ANALYZE THE FOOD WASTE GENERATED BY THESE HOUSEHOLDS; (2) DEVELOP MIXES OF FOOD WASTE THAT CAN BE ANAEROBICALLY DIGESTED TO NUTRITIVE FERTILIZERS; (3) ASSESS LOW-COST ANAEROBIC DIGESTERS FOR THEIR EFFECTIVENESS AND USABILITY IN THE TWELVE HOUSEHOLDS AND THEIR FERTILITY IN A GREENHOUSE EXPERIMENT; AND (4) PRODUCE OUTREACH MATERIAL TO FACILITATE THE UPSCALING OF ANAEROBIC DIGESTION OF FOOD SCRAPS IN HOUSEHOLDS. THIS PROJECT ALIGNS WITH EPA'S SUPPORT OF REDUCING FOOD WASTE, LIMITING GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS, AND MINIMIZING LAND FILL MATERIALS.

THIS AWARD PROVIDES FUNDS FOR THE RECIPIENT, COLORADO FOUNDATION FOR AGRICULTURE, TO IMPLEMENT AN OUTREACH AND EDUCATION PROJECT FOCUSED ON REDUCTION OF FOOD WASTE. THE RECIPIENT WILL PRODUCE AND DISTRIBUTE A STUDENT ACTIVITY NEWSPAPER THAT IS DISTRIBUTED TO ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS IN COLORADO.  THE PROJECT WILL ALSO INCLUDE A DIGITIALLY ARCHIVED DOCUMENT, THAT HAS THE POTENTIAL TO REACH A BROADER AUDIENCE. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN AN INCREASE IN RECYCLING AND REUSE OF MATERIALS AND RESOURCES, PRIMARLY FOCUSED ON FOOD WASTE.

DESCRIPTION:THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT AWARDS FEDERAL FUNDS IN THE AMOUNT OF $91,500.00 TO PROVIDE THE INSTITUTE FOR LOCAL SELF-RELIANCE (ILSR)  FUNDING TO CULTIVATE COMMUNITY-SCALE AND FARM-SCALE COMPOSTING OF WASTED FOOD IN EPA MID-ATLANTIC REGION'S FIVE (5) STATES PLUS THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA. THE FUNDS WOULD SPECIFICALLY ALLOW ILSR TO EXPAND THE REACH OF EPA'S NEW ONLINE COMMUNITY COMPOSTING 101 CERTIFICATE PROGRAM IN THE MID-ATLANTIC REGION, CREATE AND DISSEMINATE COMPOSTING TRAINING MATERIALS THAT SITES CAN USE ON THEIR OWN TO ESTABLISH ONSITE COMPOSTING INFRASTRUCTURE, PRODUCE AND OFFER VIRTUAL HOME COMPOSTING TRAINING, ENHANCE THE CAPACITY OF EXISTING COMMUNITY COMPOSTERS, AND DEVELOP AN ON-FARM COMPOSTING SITE IN THE MONTGOMERY COUNTY, MARYLAND, AGRICULTURAL RESERVE. THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE THE CAPACITY OF INDIVIDUALS, FAMILIES, AND GARDENERS TO COMPOST AT HOME AND AT COMMUNITY VENUES IN ALL FIVE MID-ATLANTIC STATES AND THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA. THE FOCUS WILL BE ON IMPACTING DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES. ADVANCING COMMUNITY-SCALE COMPOSTING BUILDS APPROPRIATELY-SIZED CAPACITY IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. ACTIVITIES:ACTIVITIES INCLUDE CREATING AND DISSEMINATING COMPOSTING TRAINING MATERIALS THAT SITES CAN USE ON THEIR OWN TO ESTABLISH ONSITE COMPOSTING INFRASTRUCTURE, PRODUCE AND OFFER VIRTUAL HOME COMPOSTING TRAINING, ENHANCE THE CAPACITY OF EXISTING COMMUNITY COMPOSTERS, AND DEVELOP AN ON-FARM COMPOSTING SITE IN THE MONTGOMERY COUNTY, MARYLAND, AGRICULTURAL RESERVE. THIS PROJECT AND ITS ACTIVITIES ALSO DIRECTLY SUPPORTS SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT OF FOOD. COMMUNITY-AND-FARM-SCALE COMPOSTING DEVELOPS A LOCAL CIRCULAR ECONOMY AND COMMUNITY RESILIENCY, CONVERTING WASTED FOOD INTO A SOIL AMENDMENT TO ENHANCE LOCAL SOILS TO GROW LOCAL FOOD. COMPOST USE REDUCES THE NEED FOR PESTICIDES, HELPS MANAGE STORM WATER RUN-OFF AND SOIL EROSION, AND IMPROVES URBAN ENVIRONMENTS.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE: (1) A HOME COMPOSTING WORKSHOP VIDEO; (2) OPEN-SOURCE COMPOST SCREENER DESIGNS; (3) FOUR VIRTUAL HOME COMPOSTING WORKSHOPS; (4) THREE ON-FARM COMPOSTING WEBINARS; (5) ONE ON-FARM COMPOSTING SYSTEM BUILT AT THE AGRICULTURAL FARM HISTORY PARK IN MONTGOMERY COUNTY, MARYLAND; AND (6) ONE CASE STUDY ON THE COMPOSTING SITE DEVELOPED AT THE AGRICULTURAL FARM HISTORY PARK. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE: (1) A GREATER NUMBER OF INDIVIDUALS KNOWLEDGEABLE ABOUT COMMUNITY-SCALE COMPOSTING PROGRAMS; (2) IMPROVED ABILITY AND CAPACITY FOR INDIVIDUALS, GARDENERS, COMMUNITY VENUES, AND URBAN AND RURAL FARMS TO COMPOST FOOD WASTE; AND (3) AN INCREASED AMOUNT OF FOOD SCRAPS AND OTHER MATERIALS DIVERTED FROM LANDFILLS AND INCINERATORS.  THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THE PROJECT INCLUDE INDIVIDUALS, FAMILIES, AND GARDENERS IN ALL FIVE MID-ATLANTIC STATES AND THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA.

DESCRIPTION:
THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE ROBUST TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, TRAINING, AND CERTIFICATION TO AT LEAST 200 FOOD WASTE GENERATORS AND THEIR STAFF VIA AN INNOVATIVE ONLINE PLATFORM AND BE MADE AVAILABLE TO ALL 5,600 COMMERCIAL AND INSTITUTIONAL FOOD WASTE GENERATING BUSINESSES WITHIN THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA.  THIS PROJECT WILL UTILIZE FEDERAL GRANT FUNDS TO ESTABLISH A COMMERCIAL FOOD WASTE GENERATOR TRAINING AND CERTIFICATION PROGRAM TO BOLSTER ORGANIC WASTE DIVERSION VIA ANEROBIC DIGESTION.  IN SUPPORT OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA'S ZERO WASTE GOALS, THE NEW FOOD WASTE READY PROGRAM WILL INCREASE THE AMOUNT OF SOURCE-SEPARATED COMMERCIAL FOOD WASTE AVAILABLE FOR LOCAL ANEROBIC DIGESTION AND, THEREBY, SPUR FURTHER ANEROBIC DIGESTION INFRASTRUCTURE GROWTH WITHIN THE METROPOLITAN REGION.  THE DISTRICT WILL  DEVELOP UNIQUE CONTENT IN CONJUNCTION WITH LOCAL FOOD INDUSTRY EXPERTS AND END USERS, AND MARKET THE PROGRAM THROUGH SOCIAL MEDIA, WEBINARS, AND DIRECT MAILERS.


 
ACTIVITIES:
THE ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE PREPARING AND CERTIFYING COMMERCIAL FOOD WASTE GENERATORS (FOOD WASTE BUSINESSES) IN THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA TO SET-UP SUCCESSFUL SOURCE SEPARATED ORGANICS (SSO) PROGRAMS AND DIVERT ORGANIC MATERIAL FROM LANDFILLS. THE FOOD WASTE READY PROGRAM WILL SUPPORT ALL COMMERCIAL FOOD WASTE GENERATORS AT A TURNING POINT FOR FOOD WASTE DIVERSION IN THE DISTRICT, AND  REQUIRE AT LEAST TWO EMPLOYEES PER BUSINESS TO COMPLETE THE TRAINING, INSTALL VISIBLE SIGNAGE AND DEDICATED  SOURCE SEPARATED ORGRANICS BINS IN THE FRONT AND BACK-OF-HOUSE, AND MAINTAIN TWICE-A-WEEK COLLECTION FROM A DEDICATED ORGANICS HAULER TRANSPORTING FOOD WASTE TO LOCAL ANAEROBIC DIGESTION FACILITIES.  

OUTCOMES:
THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES WILL BE TO SUPPORT ALL COMMERCIAL FOOD WASTE GENERATORS AT A TURNING POINT FOR FOOD WASTE DIVERSION IN THE DISTRICT. LOCAL COMMERCIAL ORGANICS RECYCLING RULES WILL COME INTO EFFECT IN EARLY 2023 FOR THE LARGEST COMMERCIAL FOOD WASTE GENERATORS WHICH WILL AFFECT APPROXIMATELY FORTY (40) GROCERY STORES AND FOUR UNIVERSITIES. IN 2024, THREE SPORTS STADIUMS, FIVE HOSPITALS, AND TWO ADDITIONAL UNIVERSITIES WILL BE REQUIRED TO SOURCE SEPARATE AND DIVERT ORGANICS. THE DISTRICT WILL CONTINUE TO EXPAND THE FOOD WASTE READY PROGRAM AND SEEK TO MAKE CONTINUOUS IMPROVEMENTS BASED ON LESSONS LEARNED, THE EMERGENCE OF NEW ORGANIC WASTE FACILITIES AND HAULING FIRMS.  THE DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THE PROJECT ARE LOCAL AGENCIES AND BUSINESS EXPERTS, AS WELL AS NATIONAL EXPERTS.

THIS PROJECT LEVERAGES STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIPS TO BUILD COMMUNITY SUPPORT AND EDUCATION AND ENSURE COHESIVE MANAGEMENT. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE RAISING AWARENESS OF SUSTAINABLE FOOD WASTE MANAGEMENT PRACTICE, SUCH AS COMPOSTING OR ANAEROBIC DIGESTION, THROUGH COMMUNITY OUTREACH AND EDUCATION BY DIRECTLY ENGAGING AND EDUCATING THE LOCAL COMMUNITY IN THE UPPER MATTAPONI INDIAN TRIBE'S COMPOSTING INITIATIVE AND DEVELOPING A TRIBAL COMMUNITY GARDEN.

 THE BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE THE KING WILLIAM COUNTY PUBLIC SCHOOL STUDENTS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT AGREEMENT IS TO PROVIDE FUNDING TO THE CHICKAHOMINY INDIAN TRIBE COMMUNITY GARDEN COMPOSTING PROJECT TO DEVELOP THREE COMMUNITY GARDENS AND EIGHT COMPOSTING AREAS ON A 1.5-ACRE PLOT OF LAND.  THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO HELP INFORM THE COMMUNITY ABOUT THE METHODS AND IMPORTANCE OF HOME GARDENS AND COMPOSTING THAT WILL ENHANCE SELF-SUFFICIENCY.

THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW THE CITY OF PHILADELPHIA PARKS AND RECREATION (PPR) TO ADDRESS AN EXISTING FOOD WASTE PROCESSING GAP BY LAUNCHING A PUBLIC-PRIVATE PARTNERSHIP WITH A LOCAL FOOD COMPOSTING BUSINESS ON PARK LAND, THAT WILL PROCESS SOURCE SEPARATED ORGANICS (SSO) ANNUALLY INCLUDING FOOD SCRAPS. AN OUTREACH AND EDUCATION PROGRAM WILL ALSO BE CARRIED OUT TO SUCCESSFULLY INTEGRATE THE NEW WASTE MANAGEMENT PRACTICE INTO PPR RECREATION PROGRAMMING ALLOWING THE OPERATOR TO ADD COLLECTIONS AND INVENTORY OF PPR RECREATION CENTERS TO DETERMINE ENSURE THAT MAJORITY OF THEIR FOOD WASTE FROM MUNICIPAL TRASH COLLECTION IS BEING DIVERTED.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE FUNDING TO THE ENGAGED COMMUNITY OFFSHOOTS, INC. (ECO) CITY FARMS TO PARTNER WITH THE COMPOST CREW (CC), PRINCE GEORGE'S SOIL CONSERVATION DISTRICT (PGSCD) AND INSTITUTE FOR LOCAL SELF RELIANCE (ILSR) TO CREATE AND PROMOTE A MODEL 'COMPOST OUTPOST' (OUTPOST) FOR A DISTRIBUTED COMPOSTING/VERMICOMPOSTING NETWORK TO GENERATE THE HIGH QUALITY COMPOST NEEDED FOR HEALTHY AND SUSTAINABLE FOOD GROWTH IN AND AROUND CITIES IN EPA'S REGION 3.

THESE FUNDS WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT DEVELOPMENT OF A FOOD WASTE AND DAIRY MANURE DIGESTION SYSTEM APPROPRIATE FOR SMALL TO MID-SIZE DAIRIES (100-300 COWS).  PROJECT PERSONNEL HAVE PARTNERED WITH THE CARLISLE AREA SCHOOL DISTRICT AND A LOCAL BREWERY TO INCREASE DIVERSION OF FOOD RESIDUES TO THE FARM FOR DIGESTION AND COMPOSTING.   RESEARCH ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE ESTABLISHING THE IMPACT OF DIFFERENT FEEDSTOCK BLENDS (MANURE, CAFETERIA WASTE, BREWERY WASTE, MILK WASTE, AND COOKING OIL) ON DIGESTER PERFORMANCE AND DIGESTATE VALUE AS CROP FERTILIZER, AS WELL AS THE IMPACT OF FOOD WASTE DIGESTION ON AN EXISTING COMPOST PROGRAM. THIS PROJECT CONSISTS OF FOUR COMPONENTS: 1) THE INSTALLATION OF AN AUTOMATED ANAEROBIC DIGESTION SYSTEM FOR PROCESSING FOOD RESIDUALS AND DAIRY MANURE INTO BIOGAS FOR ELECTRICITY AND DIGESTATE PRODUCTION. 2) INCREASED DIVERSION OF FOOD RESIDUES FROM SCHOOLS AND BUSINESSES TO ANAEROBIC DIGESTION FOR ENERGY PRODUCTION. 3) RESEARCH THAT WILL  SUPPORT IMPROVED DIGESTION SYSTEM PERFORMANCE AND UTILIZATION OF DIGESTATE. 4) PROVIDE OUTREACH TO FARMERS, RECYCLING PROFESSIONALS, ACADEMICS AND THE PUBLIC TO PROMOTE ANAEROBIC DIGESTION THROUGH FIELD DAYS, CONFERENCE PRESENTATIONS, VIDEOS, YOUTH CONTENT, FACT SHEETS AND A CASE STUDY.   NOTE THAT THE HEADER OF THIS AWARD CAPTIONS IT AS A GRANT AGREEMENT WHEREAS IT IS A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT. EPA IS IMPLEMENTING A NEW GRANT SYSTEM THAT WILL SOON BE UNDERGOING ENHANCEMENTS TO ALLOW FOR MORE ACCURATE DESCRIPTIONS.

FUNDING WILL BE USED TO REACH OUT TO HIGH-VOLUME COMPOST USERS TO INCREASE COMPOST USE AND ORGANICS RECYCLING.

TO PROVIDE ANALYTICAL INFORMATION THAT REFLECTS THE IMPACTS ON END-MARKET VALUE AND EVALUATE HOW BEST TO COLLECT RECYCLABLES MAXIMIZING THE VALUE. TO ORGANIZE AND LEAD A COMPOSTING FOR COMMUNITY PROJECT IN THE MID-ATLANTIC REGION.  SPECIFICALLY, THE PROJECT WILL SUPPORT HOME AND COMMUNITY-SCALE COMPOSTING TRANINING AND TECHNICAL SUPPORT AND DEMONSTRATE THE VIABILITY OF LOCAL FOOD WASTE AND OTHER ORGANIC MATERIAL RECYCLING.

PRESENTATIONS WILL DISCUSS HOW TO SCALE EFFECTIVE SOLUTIONS AND MAKE MEANINGFUL PROGRESS TOWARDS THESE GOALS, AS WELL AS STRATEGIES FOR FOOD RECOVERY ACROSS DIFFERENT SECTORS AND RURAL AND URBAN AREAS.

RESULTS WILL FULFILL PART OF THE RAW INITIAL DATA REQUIRED TO SUPPORT THE GOVERNOR'S RECYCLING TASK FORCE AND DEVELOPMENT OF WASTE MANAGEMENT POLICY IN THE U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS.

CITIZENS COMMITTEE FOR NEW YORK CITY WILL CONDUCT A DEMONSTRATION PROJECT TO ESTABLISH A REUSABLE FOOD TAKEOUT CONTAINER PROGRAM WITHIN A LARGE CORPORATE BUILDING, DEVELOP A TOOLKIT FOR OTHERS TO IMPLEMENT SIMILAR PROGRAMS AND MAKE THIS WIDELY AVAILABLE. THE RECIPIENT PROPOSES TO PARTNER WITH THE BUILD REUSE ASSOCIATION TO DELIVER SPECIALIZED, TRAIN-THE-TRAINER EDUCATION TO INCREASE THE EFFECTIVE AND EFFICIENT MANAGEMENT OF CONSTRUCTION AND DEMOLITION MATERIALS IN THE US VIRGIN ISLANDS. TRAINEES WILL INCLUDE INFLUENTIAL CONSTRUCTION AND DEMOLITION DEBRIS LEADERS ON ALL THREE OF THE USVI SO AS TO HAVE THE MAXIMUM IMPACT UPON THE INDUSTRY.

FUNDING WILL ALSO SUPPORT PUBLIC EDUCATION THROUGHOUT THE COURSE OF THE PROJECT, AND RESULTS AND LESSONS LEARNED WILL BE SHARED AT THE CONCLUSION.

DESCRIPTION:

THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE IMPLEMENTATION OF WASTED FOOD REDUCTION, RECOVERY, AND DIVERSION MEASURES IN LARGE INSTITUTIONAL KITCHENS (E.G., HOSPITALS, UNIVERSITIES, CORPORATE KITCHENS, LARGE K-12 SCHOOLS) AND FOOD GENERATING BUSINESS (FOOD RETAILERS, MANUFACTURERS, RESTAURANTS) IN NEW YORK AND NEW JERSEY. 


ACTIVITIES:

SOURCE REDUCTION TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPERS, FOOD RESCUE ORGANIZATIONS, HAULERS AND COMPOST SITES); AND OFFERING REMOTE AND ONSITE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE (TA) FOR REDUCING, RECOVERING, AND DIVERTING WASTED FOOD.

DESCRIPTION:THE UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MEDICAL SCIENCES CAMPUS THROUGH A PARTNERSHIP WITH CORREDOR DEL YAGUAZO SEEKS TO EDUCATE THE COMMUNITY OF JUANA MATOS, LOCATED IN CATANTILDE;O, PUERTO RICO ON SOLID WASTE DIVERSION PRACTICES, INCLUDING SOURCE REDUCTION, RECYCLING, AND TRANSFORMATION TECHNIQUES. EMPHASIS WILL BE GIVEN TO ANAEROBIC DIGESTION OF FOOD WASTES AND OTHER BIODEGRADABLE MATERIALS TO PRODUCE BIOGAS. TRANSFORMATION OF BIODEGRADABLE ORGANIC MATERIALS IS VERY IMPORTANT SINCE THESE CANNOT BE RECYCLED, AND MUST BE LANDFILLED IF NOT TRANSFORMED INTO USEFUL PRODUCTS SUCH AS  BIOGAS AND DIGESTATES. A SMALL PILOT FACILITY TO PRODUCE BIOGAS WILL BE DESIGNED AND BUILT IN JUANA MATOS, TO DEMONSTRATE THE POTENTIAL BENEFITS TO THE JUANA MATOS COMMUNITY MEMBERS, TO MOTIVATE THEM TO REQUEST THE CONSTRUCTION OF A LARGER SCALE FACILITY IN THE MUNICIPALITY OF CATANTILDE;O, AND TO SERVE AS AN EXAMPLE FOR OTHER COMMUNITIES IN PUERTO RICO.ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT INCLUDES TWO MAJOR ACTIVITIES: A SEMINAR SERIES AND CONSTRUCTION AND OPERATION OF AN ANAEROBIC DIGESTION (AD) PILOT FACILITY. DURING THE FIRST YEAR OF THE PROJECT, A SERIES OF FIVE SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT SEMINARS PREPARED BY THE UPR-MSC, AND REVISED BY CORREDOR DEL YAGUAZO, WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE COMMUNITY. TOPICS INCLUDE SOLID WASTE IN GENERAL, IMPACT OF INADEQUATE MANAGEMENT, UNRECYCLABLE FOOD WASTE, BIOGAS, AND SOURCE REDUCTION. DURING THE SECOND YEAR, THE PROJECT WILL CONCENTRATE EFFORTS ON THE FINAL DESIGN, PROCUREMENT, INSTALLATION, AND START-UP OF THE PILOT BIOGAS PRODUCTION FACILITY, WHICH WILL INCLUDE A BIOGAS POWERED ELECTRICITY GENERATOR.

THE  PROPOSED  PROJECT  WILL  ALSO CONTRIBUTE  TO THE  EVALUATION  OF  OPPORTUNITIES TO  USE  (MARKETING AND/OR SALE) OF AD DIGESTATE. EL CORREDOR DEL YAGUAZO CO-MANAGES WITH THE PUERTO  RICO DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCES, A PROTECTED AREA IN CATANTILDE;O, ADJACENT TO JUANA MATOS, CALLED 'CIENAGA LAS CUCHARILLAS', WHERE A REFORESTATION PROJECT IS BEING CONDUCTED, INCLUDING A NURSERY FOR THREATENED SPECIES.  SUBRECIPIENT:THE SUBAWARD RECIPIENT, CORREDOR DEL YAGUAZO, WILL UTILIZE FUNDS TO PERFORM THE TWO MAIN ACTIVITIES OF THE GRANT. CORREDOR DEL YAGUAZO WILL UTILIZE THE SUBAWARD TO EXECUTE THE PROJECT, INCLUDING THE ORGANIZATION OF THE SEMINARS, AND THE SUPERVISION OF THE PILOT FACILITY'S DESIGN, CONSTRUCTION, AND START UP IN THE JUANA MATOS COMMUNITY.OUTCOMES:THE GRANTEE WILL BE HOSTING A KICK-OFF EVENT, FINAL EVENT, AND FIVE SEMINARS FOR A NUMBER OF COMMUNITY MEMBERS WITH THE TASK OF ADOPTING ACCOMPANYING COMMUNITY RESOLUTIONS ON SOLID WASTE AND ANAEROBIC DIGESTION (AD) TOPICS. ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE THE CONSTRUCTION AND OPERATION OF AN AD PILOT FACILITY DURING THE GRANT PERIOD AND BEYOND. THIS FACILITY IS EXPECTED TO DIVERT A NUMBER OF POUNDS OF ORGANIC MATERIAL FROM LANDFILL AND PRODUCE A COUPLE THOUSAND STANDARD CUBIC FEET OF BIOGAS DURING THE PROJECT PERIOD. DURING THE GRANT PERIOD, THE GRANTEE WILL WRITE AND SUBMIT QUARTERLY REPORTS AND A FINAL TECHNICAL REPORT.

EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF THE PROJECT INCLUDE GREATER INTEREST BY THE COMMUNITY TO PARTICIPATE IN PUBLIC POLICY DECISIONS THROUGH PARTICIPATION IN THE EDUCATIONAL AND PARTICIPATORY SEMINARS. IN ADDITION, THE PILOT AD FACILITY IS EXPECTED TO BROADEN KNOWLEDGE ON AD BY SERVING AS AN EDUCATIONAL FACILITY AND LABORATORY FOR USE BY COMMUNITY MEMBERS AND UNIVERSITY STUDENTS. OVERALL, THE PROJECT IS EXPECTED TO RESULT IN INCREASED RESOURCES AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE THROUGH EDUCATION, OUTREACH, AND TRAINING TO INDIVIDUALS AND/OR BUSINESSES ON AD THROUGH LONG TERM COLLABORATION BETWEEN UPR-MSC AND CORREDOR DEL YAGUAZO. ONE EXPECTED MEDIUM-TERM OUTCOME OF THIS PROJECT IS THE ACCELERATION OF THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEW AD INFRASTRUCTURE/CAPACITY IN OTHER COMMUNITIES/MUNICIPALITIES IN PUERTO RICO,

DESCRIPTION:NORTHEAST WASTE MANAGEMENT OFFICIALS ASSOCIATION WILL PARTNER WITH THE NORTHEAST RECYCLING COUNCIL AND TWO STATE-WIDE ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE (EJ) ORGANIZATIONS TO UNDERTAKE THE DEVELOPMENT OF GUIDANCE AND TRAINING ON EJ ENGAGEMENT AND REGULATORY COMPLIANCE TO SUPPORT ANAEROBIC DIGESTION (AD) IN COMMUNITIES. ALL ORGANIZATIONS INVOLVED IN THIS PROJECT ARE COMMITTED TO SHARING THE RESULTS OF THIS PROGRAM WITH GOVERNMENT AND PRIVATE SECTOR SUSTAINABLE MATERIALS MANAGEMENT (SMM) PROGRAMS, AD COMPANIES AND CONSULTANTS, FOOD WASTE DIVERSION AND RECYCLING ORGANIZATIONS, EJ ORGANIZATIONS, AND OTHERS.ACTIVITIES:PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: INCREASING SUPPORT FOR STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENT PROGRAMS THAT SEEK TO USE AD TO INCREASE THEIR FOOD WASTE DIVERSION RATES; DEVELOPING, MODELING, AND PROMOTING SOLUTIONS AND APPROACHES FOR INCREASING FOOD WASTE AD UTILIZATION THAT CAN BE REPLICATED BY OTHER COMMUNITIES, GOVERNMENTS, AND OTHER ENTITIES; AND PREPARING GUIDANCE MATERIALS, TRAINING, OUTREACH, AND COMPLIANCE ASSISTANCE TO ACCELERATE SOLUTIONS RELATING TO IMPROVED SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT.SUBRECIPIENT:SUBAWARDS INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING PROJECT ACTIVITIES:
- PARTICIPATION ON THE PROJECT STEERING COMMITTEE 
- REVIEW AND PROMOTION OF THE PUBLICATIONS, TRAINING WEBINARS, AND OTHER ACTIVITIES THROUGHOUT THE PROJECT 
- DEVELOPMENT OF WRITTEN MATERIALS AS DELIVERABLES OF THE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT
OUTCOMES:THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE GENERAL POPULATION OF THE NORTHEAST, THE FOOD GENERATORS, AND THE OPERATORS OF AD FACILITIES, BOTH FUTURE AND EXTANT. THE OUTCOMES/DELIVERABLES INCLUDE: A GROUP OF STATE ENVIRONMENTAL REGULATORY AND EJ STAFF TO SHARE INFORMATION ON THEIR PROGRAMS FOR THE DEVELOPMENT AND OPERATION OF AD FACILITIES, AND TO ASSIST WITH DEVELOPING A REGULATORY GUIDE AND VIRTUAL TRAINING; A GUIDE TO AIR, WATER, AND SOLID WASTE REGULATIONS IN THE 11 NORTHEAST STATES THAT APPLY TO AD DEVELOPMENT AND OPERATIONS FOR PROCESSING FOOD WASTE, AND GUIDANCE FOR SUCCESSFUL NAVIGATION OF THESE REQUIREMENTS AND RELATED STATE EJ POLICIES/LAWS; A TRAINING PROGRAM BASED ON THE REGULATORY GUIDE AND ORGANIZE FIVE VIRTUAL TRAINING WEBINARS; A BEST PRACTICE GUIDE ON EFFECTIVE ENGAGEMENT WITH EJ COMMUNITIES IN PLANNING FOR AD OPERATIONS; A ROAD MAP DESIGNED TO HELP MUNICIPAL OFFICIALS AND RESIDENTS IN EJ COMMUNITIES LEARN WHERE AD FACILITIES MAY BE LOCATED UNDERSTAND THE BASICS OF AD, THE OVERALL REGULATORY LANDSCAPE, AND THE OPPORTUNITIES AVAILABLE FOR MEANINGFUL ENGAGEMENT IN DECISION-MAKING; AND TWO VIRTUAL TRAINING WEBINARS TO PROMOTE AND SHARE THE GUIDE TO COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT AND THE ROADMAP.

DESCRIPTION:THE FOOD WASTE PREVENTION CERTIFICATE PROGRAM FOR FOOD RETAIL WORKERS WILL BE IMPLEMENTED IN MID-SIZE FOOD RETAIL BUSINESSES (GROCERY STORES) IN NEW YORK AND NEW JERSEY. THE PROJECT WILL PREVENT FOOD WASTE IN STORE OPERATIONS BY QUANTIFYING FOOD WASTE, IDENTIFYING BEST FOOD WASTE PREVENTION PRACTICES, DEVELOPING AN EMPLOYEE FOOD WASTE PREVENTION CERTIFICATE PROGRAM, PILOTING THE PROGRAM IN THREE STORES, AND MEASURING THE RESULTS OF THE CERTIFICATE PROGRAM PILOT. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN FOOD WASTE PREVENTION OF THREE TONS PER STORE PER YEAR, AND A WORKER CERTIFICATE PROGRAM THAT IS SCALABLE NATIONWIDE.ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT WILL BE IMPLEMENTED USING THE FIVE FOLLOWING STRATEGIES: 1. RESEARCH AND DOCUMENT HIGH-IMPACT EMPLOYEE FOOD WASTE MANAGEMENT AND PREVENTION PRACTICES IN THREE MID-SIZE GROCERY STORES; DOCUMENT FOOD WASTE GENERATION PRACTICES IN STORES USING OBSERVATION, INTERVIEWS, AND STORE WASTE MANAGEMENT RECORDS. 2. ESTABLISH BASELINE FOOD WASTE METRICS AND POST-PROJECT METRICS IN PARTICIPATING STORES; COLLECT FOOD WASTE PERFORMANCE DATA AT EACH STORE: UTILIZE WASTE RECORDS AND ESTABLISH LOW-COST FOOD WASTE SEGREGATION MEASURES TO CAPTURE CURRENT FOOD WASTE METRICS OVER A LIMITED PERIOD TO ESTABLISH A BASELINE FOOD WASTE MEASUREMENT FROM SPECIFIC SOURCES WITHIN THE STORE; COLLECT POST-PILOT FOOD WASTE METRICS DATA AT THE END OF THE PROJECT PERIOD TO CALCULATE FOOD WASTE PREVENTION RATES. 3. DEVELOP EMPLOYEE TRAINING CURRICULUM FOR CERTIFICATE PROGRAM BASED ON PRIMARY RESEARCH IN STORES; THE  TRAINING WILL HAVE THREE MODULES, WITH THREE TRAINING WEBINARS AND INTERACTIVE QUIZZES; DEVELOP WEBPAGE ON RATIO INSTITUTE SITE FOR CERTIFICATE PROGRAM ENROLLMENT AND DELIVERY. 4. PILOT CERTIFICATE PROGRAM IN 3 STORES INVOLVING 15-30 EMPLOYEES: IMPLEMENT THE CERTIFICATE PROGRAM WITH 15-30 EMPLOYEES IN 3 STORES, OR 5-10 EMPLOYEES PER STORE. 5. INTEGRATE LEARNINGS AND PACKAGE CERTIFICATE PROGRAM TO SHARE WITH WIDER INDUSTRY VIA DIGITAL CHANNELS; COMPILE RESULTS OF PILOT CERTIFICATE PROGRAM INTO A WHITE PAPER TO BE MADE AVAILABLE TO GROCERS ACROSS REGION 2 AND OTHER EPA REGIONS; CERTIFICATE PROGRAM WILL BE SHARED WITH RETAILERS ACROSS NORTH AMERICA THROUGH RATIO INSTITUTE'S WEBSITE, SOCIAL CHANNELS, AND PRESS RELEASE CHANNELS.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO PREVENT 6000 POUNDS OF FOOD WASTE PER STORE PER YEAR THROUGH THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PILOT FOOD WASTE PREVENTION CERTIFICATE PROGRAM AIMED AT INDEPENDENT GROCERS AND SMALL GROCERY CHAINS, OR A TOTAL OF 18,000 POUNDS OF FOOD WASTE PREVENTED DURING THE FUNDING PERIOD. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE STORE'S OWNERS, WHO WILL BENEFIT FROM MORE EFFICIENT GARBAGE PRODUCTION AND INCREASED COST SAVINGS, THE SURROUNDING COMMUNITIES, WHICH WILL PROFIT FROM INCREASED FOOD DONATIONS AND REDUCED GARBAGE PRODUCTION, AND THE ENTIRE PLANET, WHICH WILL PROFIT FROM REDUCED NATURAL RESOURCE CONSUMPTION, DECREASED WASTE DISPOSAL AND REDUCED GREENHOUSE GAS PRODUCTION.

DESCRIPTION:SCHOOL CAFETERIA WASTE REDUCTION INTERVENTIONS FOR CLIMATE SMART FOOD SERVICE IS A SERIES OF SEQUENTIAL SOURCE REDUCTION PILOTS TO BE SHARED CITYWIDE AS A SCALABLE MODEL TO ACCELERATE NEW YORK CITY'S ZERO WASTE GOALS. THE PROJECT FOCUS IS ON MINIMIZING BOTH SCHOOL FOOD PACKAGING AND FOOD WASTE AT ONE NEW YORK CITY PUBLIC ELEMENTARY SCHOOL USING DETAILED WASTE AUDITS, VIDEO DOCUMENTATION, CLASSROOM EDUCATION, AND STUDENT AND STAFF PARTNERSHIP.ACTIVITIES:THIS DEMONSTRATION PROJECT WILL TAKE PLACE AT P.S. 15 PATRICK F. DALY IN RED HOOK, BROOKLYN, SPANNING ACROSS TWO SCHOOL YEARS, PARTNERING WITH STUDENTS AND SCHOOL STAFF. WITH THE SUPPORT OF LONG-TIME AGENCY PARTNERS NYC DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION AND OFFICES OF FOOD AND NUTRITION AND SUSTAINABILITY, THE TEAM WILL: CONDUCT FOUR KEY INTERVENTIONS TO TEST NEW WASTE REDUCTION METHODOLOGIES; COLLECT DETAILED BASELINE AND DAY-OF-PILOT CAFETERIA WASTE DATA, DEVELOP AND TEACH RELATED CLASSROOM CURRICULUM WITH STUDENT-DESIGNED ENGAGEMENT CAMPAIGNS, VIDEO DOCUMENT THE PROCESS, AND FINALLY, PRESENT QUALITATIVE AND QUANTITATIVE OUTCOMES AND STUDENT SUGGESTIONS TO DECISION-MAKERS TO ACCELERATE THE REDUCTION OF LANDFILL AND INCINERATOR-BOUND SCHOOL GARBAGE FROM ALL 1,800 NYC PUBLIC SCHOOLS.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE DOCUMENTED REDUCTION IN SINGLE USE PLASTIC CONSUMPTION IN PS 15; EXPANSION OF THE PLASTIC-FREE LUNCH DAY TO ALL 1800 NYC PUBLIC SCHOOLS; AND EXPANSION OF THE PILOT LUNCH DEMONSTRATION TO INCLUDE BREAKFAST, FURTHER REDUCING SINGLE USE PLASTIC CONSUMPTION. INTENDED BENEFIIARIES ARE NEW YORK CITY RESIDENTS AND INDIRECTLY, ALL GLOBAL CITIZENS, AS ONE OF THE ENVIRONMENTAL GOALS IS A REDUCTION IN GREENHOUSE GASES PRODUCED.

DESCRIPTION:WASTED FOOD SOLUTIONS (WFS) FOR DENVER PHASE II WILL APPLY FINDINGS FROM THE INITIAL PHASE OF THIS PROJECT TO IMPLEMENT STRATEGIES THAT INCREASE PARTICIPATION IN AND ADOPTION OF FOOD 
 DONATION EFFORTS. WFS FOR DENVER PHASE II WILL CONNECT WITH LOCAL FOOD BUSINESSES, FOOD BANKS, FOOD RESCUE ORGANIZATIONS, AND LOCAL GOVERNMENT TO CAPTURE SUCCESS STORIES OF DONATION WHILE HONING SUPPORT MATERIALS THAT SPUR FOOD RECOVERY. THIS PROJECT WILL CULMINATE IN A CAMPAIGN THAT DRAWS ON COMMUNITY BASED SOCIAL MARKETING TECHNIQUES TO INSPIRE NEW BUSINESSES TO DONATE SURPLUS EDIBLE FOOD. ACTIVITIES:FUNDING FOR PHASE II WILL ALLOW CET TO RESPOND TO LESSONS LEARNED DURING PHASE I AND CREATE TAILOR-MADE CONTENT WE NOW KNOW DENVER PARTNERS NEED. FUNDING WILL ALSO ENABLE ONGOING EDUCATIONAL EFFORTS, NETWORKING, AND TA WITH GENERATORS AND SERVICE PROVIDERS TO SUPPORT COLLABORATION AND FACILITATE NEW OPPORTUNITIES FOR FOOD  RECOVERY. THUS, BASED ON THE FINDINGS FROM PHASE I, CET PROPOSES THE FOLLOWING REFINED ACTIVITIES FOR WASTED  FOOD SOLUTIONS FOR DENVER PHASE II: BUILDING FOUNDATIONS FOR FOOD RECOVERY SOLUTIONS- WHICH WILL DRAW ON  LESSONS LEARNED FROM PHASE I WHILE PROVIDING DIRECT ASSISTANCE TO 1-2 BUSINESS TO ESTABLISH NEW DONATION PROGRAMS AND CULTIVATING STORIES OF CURRENT DONORS; AND CATALYZING CHANGE FOR FOOD RECOVERY - A PROCESS THAT LEVERAGES ACTIVITY 1 TO CREATE SOCIAL NORMS, INCENTIVIZE PARTICIPATION, AND DEVELOP PROMPTS AND REMINDERS TO INCREASE FOOD RECOVERY ACTIVITY. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, CET WILL EMPLOY COMMUNITY BASED SOCIAL MARKETING (CBSM) TECHNIQUES TO ADDRESS BARRIERS TO WIDESPREAD ADOPTION OF FOOD RECOVERY AND WASTE REDUCTION STRATEGIES. AS BUSINESSES FOCUS ON FOOD RECOVERY THERE IS A NATURAL TENDENCY TO INCREASE AWARENESS AT ALL LEVELS OF THE EPA FOOD RECOVERY HIERARCHY, OFFERING ADDED RESULTS FOR PREVENTION AND SOURCE SEPARATION ACTIVITIES AS WELL.  CET WILL CARRY OUT THIS 12-MONTH PROJECT IN COLLABORATION WITH DDPHE WHILE ENGAGING WITH A ROBUST NETWORK OF LOCAL STAKEHOLDERS TO SPUR INCREASED FOOD DONATION ACTIVITY. AS BUSINESSES CONTINUE TO REOPEN IN THE AFTERMATH OF COVID-19, THE COST SAVINGS POTENTIAL OF WASTED FOOD PREVENTION AND RECOVERY (REUSE) IS MORE COMPELLING THAN EVER. RESTAURANTS' PREVENTING FOOD WASTE CAN CUT COSTS BY 2-6%1. COMMUNITY NEED IS ALSO COMPELLING, THE DENVER FOOD VISION STATES THAT, '1 IN 6 DENVER RESIDENTS AND 1 IN 5 CHILDREN AND YOUTH EXPERIENCED FOOD INSECURITY' DEFINED AS EATING LESS THAN THEY FELT THEY SHOULD IN THE PAST YEAR BECAUSE THERE WAS NOT ENOUGH 
MONEY FOR FOOD. IT IS EXPECTED THAT THESE PERCENTAGES GREW IN THE AFTERMATH OF COVID-19. THE COMMUNITY BENEFIT OF REDUCING WASTE AND RECOVERING EDIBLE FOOD TO REDISTRIBUTE IN OUR COMMUNITIES, AS WELL AS SUPPORTING THE FUNCTION AND SUCCESS OF FOOD RESCUE ORGANIZATIONS CORRELATES TO EPA REGION'S 8 PRIORITIES MENTIONED ABOVE. 

IN ADDITION, THIS PROJECT LINKS TO SEVERAL OF THE U.S. EPA'S STRATEGIC PLAN FY 2017 - 2022 OBJECTIVES: REDUCING ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS OF MATERIALS (DIVERTING EDIBLE, SURPLUS FOR REUSE AND RECOVERY); DECREASING DISPOSAL RATES (INCREASING FOOD RECOVERY REDUCES TRASH VOLUMES AND ASSOCIATED COSTS); INCREASING SOCIOECONOMIC BENEFITS (SUPPORTING LOCAL FOOD RESCUE ORGANIZATIONS AND FOOD BANKS); AND INCREASING CAPACITY OF STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS TO ADOPT AND IMPLEMENT SMM POLICIES, PRACTICES, AND INCENTIVES (REFINING EXISTING TOOLS AND IMPLEMENTING A CAMPAIGN USING CBSM TOOLS TO INCENTIVIZE FOOD RECOVERY). FURTHER, THIS PROJECT ALIGNS WITH THE U.S. EPA'S STRATEGIC PLAN FY 2022 - 2026 OBJECTIVES: GOAL 1: TACKLE THE CLIMATE CRISIS - OBJECTIVE 1.1: REDUCE EMISSIONS THAT CAUSE CLIMATE CHANGE (REDIRECTING SURPLUS FOOD TO HUNGRY PEOPLE THUS AVOIDING THE IMPACT OF DISPOSAL AND ADDITIONAL PRODUCTION); AND GOAL 6: SAFEGUARD AND REVITALIZE COMMUNITIES - OBJECTIVE 6.2: REDUCE WASTE AND PREVENT ENVIRONMENTAL CONTAMINATION (REDUCING WASTED FOOD). DESCRIPTION:THE VALLEY ROOTS FOOD HUB (VRFH) IS A PROGRAM OF THE SAN LUIS VALLEY LOCAL FOODS COALITION
(LFC), WHOSE MISSION IS TO FOSTER AN EQUITABLE LOCAL FOOD SYSTEM THAT RESTORES THE HEALTH OF THE
PEOPLE, COMMUNITY, ECONOMY, AND ECOSYSTEM. VRFH IS A WHOLESALE AGGREGATOR AND DISTRIBUTOR OF
LOCAL PRODUCE AND VALUE-ADDED PRODUCTS FROM AREA FARMERS TO REGIONAL RESTAURANTS, INSTITUTIONS,
AND CUSTOMERS ACROSS THE SAN LUIS VALLEY (SLV) AND INTO COLORADO'S FRONT RANGE AND WESTERN
SLOPE. VRFH PROMOTES ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AROUND A LOCAL FOOD SYSTEM AND SERVES FAMILY
FARMS BY FILLING A GAP BETWEEN LOCAL, SMALL-SCALE FARMERS AND LOCAL PLATES.

VRFH IS LOCATED WITHIN A UNIQUE CAMPUS OF AGRICULTURAL BUSINESSES IN MOSCA, COLORADO, JUST
NORTH OF THE SAN LUIS VALLEY'S COMMERCIAL HUB OF ALAMOSA. ASIDE FROM VRFH'S AGGREGATION AND
DISTRIBUTION WAREHOUSE, THE CAMPUS ALSO CONTAINS A POTATO AND QUINOA PACKAGING FACILITY, AND WILL
SOON BE HOME TO A VALUE-ADDED POTATO DISTILLERY AND BIODIESEL PLANT. ALL OF THESE ENTERPRISES
PROVIDE AN ABUNDANCE OF ORGANIC FOOD WASTE MATERIAL. VRFH CURRENTLY USES COMPOSTING TO
PROCESS SOME OF THIS MATERIAL, BUT THE NEED FOR RENEWABLE ORGANIC WASTE MANAGEMENT IS
EXPANDING, AND THE OPPORTUNITY TO DEMONSTRATE NEW TECHNOLOGIES IN THE SLV IS IMMENSE.
WITH ASSISTANCE FROM AN EPAANAEROBIC DIGESTION COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT, VRFH WILL INSTALL A
HIGH-EFFICIENCY ANAEROBIC DIGESTION SYSTEM TO PROCESS FOOD AND ORGANIC WASTE AT ITS MOSCA
CAMPUS. THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE THE USE OF ANAEROBIC DIGESTION (AD) TO MANAGE ORGANIC
MATERIALS WHILE ALSO PRODUCING FUEL TO BE RECYCLED BACK INTO THE PROCESSING AND COOKING
OPERATIONS AT THE MOSCA CAMPUS.
ACTIVITIES:THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL DEMONSTRATE THE TECHNOLOGICAL FEASIBILITY AND COST-EFFECTIVENESS OF
SUCH A PROJECT IN THE RURAL, HIGH-ALPINE SLV REGION OF COLORADO. INNOVATIVE METHODS AND
APPROACHES WILL BE INCORPORATED, INCLUDING SOLAR HEATING, CAST CONCRETE, HYDRAULIC-PRESSURE BIOGAS
GASHOLDERS, AND ALGAE SCRUBBERS (FURTHER DESCRIBED IN QUESTION 9). THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE
CREATION OF A RENEWABLE ENERGY PARK AT THE MOSCA CAMPUS, WHERE THE OUTPUTS OF ONE
MICRO-INDUSTRY ARE THE INPUTS FOR ANOTHER. PLANS FOR THE CAMPUS ALSO INCLUDE A WOOD CHIP
GASIFICATION SYSTEM FOR PROCESSING HEAT THAT GENERATES BIOCHAR. WHEN COMBINED WITH DIGESTATE,
BIOCHAR HAS SHOWN PROMISE TO BUILD UP DEPLETED SOILS FOR BETTER WATER RETENTION AND NUTRIENT
BIOAVAILABILITY. THE PARK WILL BE A DEMONSTRATION AND EDUCATIONAL SPACE FOR LEARNING AND SHARING
THE BENEFITS OF AD AND OTHER FORMS OF RENEWABLE ENERGY POSSIBLE IN THE SLV AND AROUND THE
COUNTRY.
SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:RESULTS WILL BE SHARED AMONG THE AGRICULTURAL COMMUNITY, BUSINESSES, RESEARCHERS, EDUCATORS, AND
OTHER PARTNERS ACROSS THE REGION AND BEYOND. OUR TEAM WILL CREATE REPORTS ALONG THE WAY OF
SUCCESSES, MILESTONES, AND LESSONS LEARNED. TOURS WILL BE OFFERED TO EDUCATORS, STUDENTS,
GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, AND OTHER INTERESTED PARTIES. FINALLY, VRFH GENERAL MANAGER, NICHOLAS
CHAMBERS, IS AN ADJUNCT INSTRUCTOR AT SANTA FE COMMUNITY COLLEGE'S (SFCC) BIOFUELS LAB AND
WILL INCORPORATE THIS PROJECT'S PLANNING, ENGINEERING, CONSTRUCTION, AND OPERATION INTO THE
CURRICULUM. IN THE FUTURE, CLASSES, RETREATS, AND EVENTS WILL BE HELD AT THE SITE BY SFCC AND OTHER
ORGANIZATIONS TO CONTINUE THE LEARNING AND SHARING OF IDEAS.

THIS SYSTEM WILL BE INNOVATIVE AND UNIQUE FOR THE SLV AND WILL PROVIDE NUMEROUS OPPORTUNITIES
FOR DEMONSTRATION, EDUCATION, AND EXPANSION INTO OTHER PARTS OF THE REGION. AGRICULTURE IS THE
MAIN ECONOMIC DRIVER IN THE SLV, SO THERE ARE EXCITING OPPORTUNITIES TO EXPAND ANAEROBIC
DIGESTION AS A METHOD FOR PROCESSING ORGANIC MATERIAL BY-PRODUCTS AT OTHER BUSINESSES AND
OPERATIONS. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO CREATE NEW AD CAPACITY FOR THE REGION AND IDENTIFY STRATEGIES TO
MANAGE ORGANIC MATERIALS.

WASTED FOOD SOLUTIONS (WFS) FOR DENVER WILL IDENTIFY STRATEGIES TO INCREASE PARTICIPATION IN AND ADOPTION OF FOOD DONATION EFFORTS. WFS FOR DENVER WILL CONNECT WITH LOCAL GOVERNMENT AGENCIES AND FOOD BUSINESSES, AS WELL AS FOOD BANKS AND FOOD RESCUE ORGANIZATIONS TO EVALUATE THE EFFICACY OF EXISTING STRATEGIES AND ASSETS. FINDINGS FROM THIS WORK WILL BE SYNTHESIZED INTO A REPORT THAT OFFERS DENVER A ROADMAP FOR FURTHERING DIVERSION WHILE DRAWING ON PROVEN COMMUNITY BASED SOCIAL MARKETING TECHNIQUES FOR EXPONENTIAL BENEFITS. THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES EPA'S NEED FOR PROJECTS FOCUSED ON SOURCE REDUCTION.

EXPECTED OUTCOMES AND OUTPUTS INCLUDE:  SOLICIT FEEDBACK FROM STAKEHOLDERS, AND REVIEW CURRENT FOOD RECOVERY EFFORTS IN DENVER, DEVELOP A COMPREHENSIVE ROADMAP OF EFFECTIVE AND EFFICIENT STRATEGIES FOR FURTHERING, BENEFICIAL REUSE OF EDIBLE FOOD IN DENVER, IDENTIFY FOOD RECOVERY BEST PRACTICES, AND INCREASE AWARENESS AND CAPACITY FOR BENEFICIAL REUSE OF EDIBLE FOOD

THE AIM OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ASSESS THE FEASIBILITY OF A COMMUNITY-WIDE REUSABLE TO-GO CONTAINER PROGRAM, INCLUDING A RAPID PILOT TESTING A PRODUCT-SERVICE SYSTEM PROTOTYPE. THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN SOURCE REDUCTION OF SINGLE-USE TO-GO CONTAINERS, LAUNCH AN EFFICIENT CONTAINER REUSE SYSTEM, AND IMPROVE MARKETS BY REMOVING CONTAMINATED TO-GO CONTAINERS FROM RECYCLING STREAMS. PROJECT OUTREACH WILL INCLUDE ELEMENTS OF COMMUNITY BASED SOCIAL MARKETING. SUSTAINABILITY LIFE CYCLE ASSESSMENTS (SLCA) WILL BE PERFORMED ON THREE (3) POTENTIAL CONTAINER TYPES, INCLUDING POLYPROPYLENE, ALUMINUM, AND SILICONE PROTOTYPES, AS WELL AS A HIGHER LEVEL SLCA OF THE PRODUCT-SERVICE SYSTEM.

THIS PROJECT AWARDS FUNDS FOR THE RECIPIENT, UTAH STATE UNIVERSITY, TO IMPLEMENT ITS OWN PROJECT TO PUBLISH, DESIGN, PRODUCE AND DISTRIBUTE ONE UTAH AGRICULTURE IN THE CLASSROOM FOOD WASTE AGREADER. THE FOOD WASTE AGREADER WILL BE DISTRIBUTED TO 500 MIDDLE/JUNIOR-HIGH SCHOOLS ACROSS UTAH WITH A FOCUS ON ISSUES RELATED TO DOMESTIC/GLOBAL FOOD WASTE, FOOD LOSS VERSUS FOOD WASTE, THE FOOD RECOVERY HIERARCHY, AND PROBLEM-BASED AND COMMUNITY-ENGAGED LEARNING ACTIVITIES RELATED TO REDUCING AND/OR ELIMINATING FOOD WASTE IN HOMES, SCHOOL, AND COMMUNITY. THE OUTCOME OF STUDENTS' LEARNING IS ANTICIPATED TO BE CHANGES IN KNOWLEDGE, CHANGES IN ATTITUDE, AND CHANGES IN BEHAVIOR REGARDING REDUCING OR ELIMINATING FOOD WASTE.

DESCRIPTION:THE ASSOCIATION OF STATE AND TERRITORIAL SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT OFFICIALS (ASTSWMO) IS A NONPROFIT ENVIRONMENTAL TRADE ASSOCIATION REPRESENTING THE WASTE MANAGEMENT AND REMEDIATION PROGRAMS WITHIN THE 50 U.S. STATES, FIVE TERRITORIES AND THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA (STATES /MEMBERS). ASTSWMO'S MISSION, ADOPTED AS PART OF ASTSWMO'S 2020-2024 STRATEGIC PLAN, IS 'TO ENHANCE AND PROMOTE EFFECTIVE STATE AND TERRITORIAL PROGRAMS AND TO AFFECT RELEVANT NATIONAL POLICIES FOR WASTE AND MATERIALS MANAGEMENT, ENVIRONMENTALLY SUSTAINABLE PRACTICES, AND ENVIRONMENTAL RESTORATION.' OUR STRATEGIC PLAN INCLUDES THREE GOALS PERTINENT TO THE PURPOSE OF THE PROPOSAL: PROVIDE ASSISTANCE TO THE MEMBERSHIP (STATES); STRENGTHEN AND DEVELOP STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIPS IN OUR ADVOCACY OF MEMBER INTEREST AT THE FEDERAL LEVEL; AND ENSURE A SUSTAINABLE ORGANIZATION FOR OUR MEMBERSHIP.
THE PURPOSE OF THE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO PROMOTE AND STIMULATE INFORMATION EXCHANGE AMONG STATE HAZARDOUS AND SOLID WASTE OFFICIALS, AND OTHER STATE OFFICIALS ACTIVELY OR POTENTIALLY INVOLVED IN THE MANAGEMENT OF THESE WASTES TO JOINTLY RESOLVE RESOURCE CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY (RCRA) ISSUES, AND IDENTIFY EMERGING ISSUES THAT ARE AT STATE AND/OR FEDERAL LEVELS.ACTIVITIES:THE ASSOCIATION OF STATE AND TERRITORIAL SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT OFFICIALS (ASTSWMO) PRIMARY FUNCTIONS ARE TO PROMOTE EFFECTIVE STATE PROGRAMS, ENHANCE THE STATE AND
FEDERAL PARTNERSHIPS, AND PROVIDE MEMBER STATES TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, TRAINING AND FORUMS FOR INFORMATION EXCHANGE. THESE FUNCTIONS ASSIST MEMBER STATE PROGRAMS IN DEVELOPING THEIR PROGRAM CAPABILITIES AND MANAGING THEIR PROGRAMS IN THE MOST EFFICIENT AND EFFECTIVE MANNER POSSIBLE. AN ADDITIONAL FEATURE OF ASTSWMO'S NON-PROFIT APPROACH IS ITS RELATIVE OBJECTIVITY. ASTSWMO REPRESENTS THE BALANCED INTEREST OF ALL STATE MEMBER PROGRAMS, WHICH NECESSITATES CONSIDERATION OF ALL SIDES OF ANY GIVEN ISSUE. COLLECTIVE VIEWS AND SOUNDING BOARD RESPONSES CAN BE GAINED QUICKLY VIA THE ASSOCIATION.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:THE WORK OF THE SUBCOMMITTEES WILL ACHIEVE THESE OUTPUTS:
O IMPROVED GPRA DEVELOPMENT PROCESS.
O PROVIDE OPPORTUNITY FOR UP TO TWO PERSONS PER STATE (I.E., STATE RCRA MANAGERS AND/OR
THEIR STAFF) TO PARTICIPATE IN EPA SPONSORED ANNUAL RCRA NATIONAL MEETINGS.
O INCREASE IN THE NUMBER OF STATE RCRA MANAGERS AND THEIR STAFF PARTICIPATING IN EPA
SPONSORED RCRA TRAINING OR OTHER WORKSHOPS.
O PROVIDE OPPORTUNITY FOR STATE REGULATORY PERSONNEL TO PARTICIPATE IN FULL 50 STATE REVIEWS
(OR SELECTED STATE REVIEWS AS APPROPRIATE) OF EPA DRAFT REGULATIONS, POLICY, GUIDANCE AND
GPRA GOAL DEVELOPMENT AS REQUESTED.
O PROVIDE OPPORTUNITY FOR STATE REGULATORY PERSONNEL TO PARTICIPATE IN FULL 50 STATE REVIEWS
(OR SELECTED STATE REVIEWS AS APPROPRIATE) OF EPA TECHNICAL AND/OR RISK INFORMATION AS
REQUESTED.
O PARTICIPATION OF OFFICIALS FROM APPROPRIATE STATE AGENCIES (TRANSPORTATION, HEALTHCARE
FACILITIES, SOLID AND HAZARDOUS WASTE, EDUCATION, ETC.) IN THE IN SMM-RELATED MEETINGS,
SOLID WASTE MANAGERS CONFERENCE, WORK GROUPS, AND MEETINGS.
O DEVELOPMENT AND PRODUCTION OF WEBINARS, REPORTS, ASSESSMENTS, TOOLS, AND RESOURCES FOR
SHARING OF INFORMATION AMONG STATE AGENCIES AND WITH EPA.
O DEVELOPMENT AND DISSEMINATION OF TRAINING AND INFORMATIONAL MATERIALS, RESEARCH TOOLS,
GUIDANCE MATERIALS, AND POLICY OPTIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS IN AREAS OF PRODUCT
STEWARDSHIP, RECYCLING, AND REDUCTION AND IMPROVED MANAGEMENT OF PRIORITY CHEMICALS.

PROJECT ONE WILL FUND TRAININGS, INCLUDING THE TRIBAL LANDS AND ENVIRONMENT FORUM (TLEF), FOR TRIBAL CO-REGULATORS ON OLEM-RELATED TOPICS OF INTEREST TO TRIBES INCLUDING SOLID AND HAZARDOUS WASTE, UNDERGROUND STORAGE TANKS, BROWNFIELDS, EMERGENCY RESPONSE, ETC. THESE TRAININGS BUILD TRIBAL CAPACITY, PROMOTE PRESERVATION AND RESTORATION OF LANDS, AND ENCOURAGE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PREPAREDNESS IN INDIAN COUNTRY. PROJECT ONE ALSO INCLUDES SUPPORT FOR TRIBAL MEMBERS OF THE TRIBAL WASTE AND RESPONSE STEERING COMMITTEE (TWAR SC), A TRIBAL PARTNERSHIP GROUP WHOSE MEMBERS PROVIDE EPA WITH TRIBAL CO-REGULATOR PERSPECTIVES ON OLEM PROGRAMS AND DISCUSS POLICY AND TECHNICAL ISSUES WITH EPA AT THE NATIONAL LEVEL. FINALLY, PROJECT ONE FUNDS ONLINE RESOURCES AND INFORMATION FOR TRIBES ABOUT OLEM-RELATED TOPICS AND ACTIVITIES.

THE CITY OF MADISON, WISCONSIN WILL CONDUCT A FEASIBILITY ANALYSIS ON DEVELOPING A REGIONAL ORGANIC WASTE COLLECTION PROGRAM FOR THE CITY AND SURROUNDING COMMUNITIES IN DANE COUNTY.  THE PROPOSED FACILITY IS INTENDED TO RECOVER ENERGY AND COMPOST FROM THE ANAEROBIC DIGESTION OF MUNICIPAL SOURCE SEPARATED ORGANICS FROM HOUSEHOLDS, RESTAURANTS AND GROCERY STORES.

THIS PROJECT WILL FUND THE PURCHASE AND INSTALLATION OF STORAGE TANKS, PIPING, ASSOCIATED SUPPLIES, THE PURCHASE OF A COMPOSITE SAMPLER, AND LABORATORY ANALYSIS OF WASTEWATER SAMPLES, TO ENABLE BUSINESSES PARTICIPATING IN FOOD AND BEVERAGE SECTOR 'COHORTS' TO SEPARATE AND DIVERT HIGH STRENGTH PROCESS WASTES TO SERVE AS ANAEROBIC DIGESTER FEEDSTOCKS.THE INFRASTUCTURE WILL BE INSTALLED IN BUSINESSES PARTICIPATING IN COHORTS, WHICH ARE BUSINESSES WHO FORMALLY COMMIT TO MAKING IMPROVEMENTS IN MULTIPLE AREAS SUCH AS ENERGY EFFICIENCY, WATER USE, AND WASTE GENERATION, AND TO WORK TOWARDS MEMBERSHIP IN THE VT GREEN BUSINESS PROGRAM, ADMINISTERED BY EAO.

WASHINGTON STATE UNIVERSITY ENERGY PROGRAM WILL PREPARE AND PRESENT A SERIES OF AT LEAST FOUR WORKSHOPS THROUGHOUT WASHINGTON STATE TO PROMOTE THE EXPANSION OF RENEWABLE NATURAL GAS (RNG) THROUGH ANAEROBIC DIGESTION (AD) PROJECTS BY WASTEWATER TREATMENT FACILITIES, AGRICULTURE PRODUCERS, FOOD PROCESSING COMPANIES, AND MUNICIPAL SOLID WASTE AGENCIES. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, OUTREACH, EDUCATION AND TRAINING TO MODEL AND ACCELERATE SOLUTIONS.

THE APPLICANT SHALL PROVIDE FOUR TRAINING COURSES, THE SPECIFIC TRAINING COURSES ARE AS FOLLOWS: 1) MANAGING HOUSEHOLD HAZARDOUS WASTE COLLECTION AT TRANSFER STATIONS; 2) MANAGING WASTED FOOD AND OTHER ORGANIC MATERIALS; 3) DEVELOPING AND UPDATING INTEGRATED WASTE MANAGEMENT PLANS; AND 4) IMPLEMENTING INTEGRATED WASTE MANAGEMENT PLANS THROUGH WASTE DIVERSION PROGRAMS. THE TRAINING COURSES SHOULD INCLUDE TRIBAL SPEAKERS THAT HAVE DEVELOPED AND IMPLEMENTED SUCCESSFUL WASTE MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS. THE RECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE TRAVEL SCHOLARSHIPS TO SUPPORT TRIBAL ATTENDANCE AT THE TRAININGS.

SUPPORT AND IMPROVE FURTHER WITH FOOD: CENTER FOR FOOD LOSS AND WASTE SOLUTIONS (WWW.FURTHERWITHFOOD.ORG). THIS PROJECT AIMS TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF U.S. ORGANIZATIONS, INDIVIDUALS, AND BUSINESSES WITH ACCESS TO QUALITY INFORMATION, TOOLS, AND APPROACHES TO REDUCE FOOD LOSS AND WASTE THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEW TOOLS AND SOLUTIONS. SPECIFICALLY, THE PROPOSAL ENVISIONS SIGNIFICANT GROWTH OF FURTHER WITH FOOD BY EXPANDING THE RESOURCE BASE, CONSOLIDATING OPPORTUNITIES FOR WEBSITE VISITORS TO GET ACTIVELY INVOLVED IN FOOD WASTE REDUCTION EFFORTS, AGGREGATE NEWS AND SOCIAL MEDIA SOURCES TO INCREASE AWARENESS AROUND ONGOING PROJECTS, MANAGE THE GROWTH OF THE COALITION, IDENTIFY RESEARCH NEEDS, PROVIDE OUTREACH, AND MEASURE IMPACT.

SPECIFICALLY, THE TRANINGS WILL FOCUS ON IMPLEMENTING INTEGRATED WASTE MANAGMENT PLANS THROUGH WASTE DIVERSION PROGRAMS.  IN ADDITION, THE RECIPIENT WILL OFFER TRAVEL SCHOLARSHIPS TO SUPPORT THE TRAININGS AS WELL AS TRAVEL SCHOLARSHIPS TO THE TRIBES THAT WILL PARTICIPATE IN THE NATIONAL TRIBAL WASTE MANAGEMENT PEER MATCHING PROGRAM.

DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO PROVIDE FUNDING THAT WOULD ALLOW THE VILLAGE OF ALAKANUK IN COLLABORATION WITH THE VILLAGE OF KOTLIK, THE NATIVE VILLAGE OF NUNAM IQUA, AND EMMONAK VILLAGE TO CONDUCT A PROJECT TO IMPROVE THE MANAGEMENT OF SOLID WASTE IN THEIR COMMUNITIES.ACTIVITIES:AS PART OF THIS PROJECT THE VILLAGE OF ALAKANUK, THE VILLAGE OF KOTLIK, THE NATIVE VILLAGE OF NUNAM IQUA, AND EMMONAK VILLAGE WILL 1) WORK COLLABORATIVELY TO IDENTIFY SOLID WASTE CONCERNS, 2) TRAIN STAFF AND COMMUNITY ON CURRENT AND FUTURE SOLID WASTE BEST PRACTICES, 3) CONDUCT SITE ASSESSMENTS IN EACH VILLAGE, 4) WORK ON NEXT STEPS FOR FUTURE BACKHAUL EFFORTS, AND 5) DOCUMENT AND SHARE PROJECT. SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:THE ACTIVITIES UNDER THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT AND PROTECT PUBLIC HEALTH BY IMPROVING SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT IN ALAKANUK, KOTLIK, NUNAM IQUA, AND EMMONAK COMMUNITIES, RESULTING IN A CLEANER, HEALTHIER, ENVIRONMENT.

DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO PROVIDE FUNDING THAT WILL ALLOW THE KALISPEL INDIAN COMMUNITY OF THE KALISPEL RESERVATION TO CREATE A DESIGN FOR A NEW TRANSFER STATION. ACTIVITIES:AS PART OF THIS PROJECT, THE KALISPEL INDIAN TRIBE WILL 1) CREATE A DESIGN PLAN FOR A NEW TRANSFER STATION; 2) CONDUCT COMMUNITY-WIDE EDUCATION AND OUTREACH ON PROPER MANAGEMENT OF HOUSEHOLD FOOD AND YARD WASTE, HOUSEHOLD HAZARDOUS WASTE, AND GLASS RECYCLING; 3) PREPARE AND SHARE DETAILED REPORT OF BEST PRACTICES AND EXPERIENCE; AND 4) SHARE DESIGN TEMPLATE WITH OTHER TRIBAL COMMUNITIES. SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:THE ACTIVITIES UNDER THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT AND PROTECT PUBLIC HEALTH BY IMPROVING SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT IN THE KALISPEL COMMUNITY, RESULTING IN A CLEANER, HEALTHIER, ENVIRONMENT.

DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO ALLOW THE CONFEDERATED TRIBES OF THE COOS, LOWER UMPQUA AND SIUSLAW INDIANS (CTCLUSI OR TRIBE) TO UPDATE THE TRIBE'S 2013 INTEGRATED SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT PLAN (ISWMP) AND IMPLEMENT THE NEW UPDATED ISWMP. ACTIVITIES:
THIS AGREEMENT WOULD ALLOW THE CONFEDERATED TRIBES OF THE COOS, LOWER UMPQUA AND SIUSLAW INDIANS (CTCLUSI OR TRIBE) TO UPDATE THEIR 2013 INTEGRATED SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT PLAN (ISWMP) AND IMPLEMENT THE NEW UPDATED ISWMP. THE UPDATE TO THE 2013 ISWMP IS A CRITICAL FIRST STEP IN ADDRESSING THE ENVIRONMENTAL, HUMAN HEALTH, AND ECONOMIC CONCERNS OCCURRING BECAUSE OF COMMUNITY AND BUSINESS GROWTH AND THE INADEQUACIES OF THE 2013 ISWMP TO MANAGE THIS CAPACITY. THIS PROJECT WILL CONSIST OF A STUDY OF CURRENT WASTES COMPOSITIONS AND ANALYZE THE WASTE MANAGEMENT FACILITIES TO ESTABLISH SYSTEM PRACTICES, ISSUES, AND EFFICACY. THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO PROVIDE TRAINING TO APPROPRIATE STAFF FOCUSING ON PROPER DISPOSAL AND WASTES REDUCTION TECHNIQUES. CTCLUSI INTENDS TO PRODUCE AND DISTRIBUTE EDUCATION AND OUTREACH MATERIALS TO COMMUNITY MEMBERS FOCUSING ON PROPER DISPOSAL, WASTE REDUCTION AND UNAUTHORIZED DUMPING PREVENTION. FURTHERMORE, THE GRANTEE HAS COMMITTED TO SHARING THE NEW ISWMP BY MAKING IT PUBLICLY AVAILABLE, AS WELL AS SHARING THEIR PROJECT SUMMARY THAT DESCRIBES CHALLENGES, SUCCESSES, USEFUL TOOLS, AND HELPFUL CONTACTS. THESE MATERIALS WILL BE ADVERTISED ON THE CTCLUSI WEBSITE, AS WELL AS DISTRIBUTED ON SELECT FORUMS FOR THE BENEFIT  OF TRIBES IN THE SURROUND OREGON AREA AS WELL AS THOSE TRIBAL COMMUNITIES NATION-WIDE VIA THE EPA REGION 10 TRIBAL LISTERV, EPA REGION 10 BROWNFIELDS LISTSERV, THE WEST COAST OCEAN ALLIANCE, THE OREGON TRIBAL PREPAREDNESS COALITION, AND OTHER FORUMS. THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT GOAL 6 (SAFEGUARD AND REVITALIZE COMMUNITIES), OBJECT 6.2. (REDUCE WASTE AND PREVENT ENVIRONMENTAL CONTAMINATION).SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:
UPDATING THE 2013 INTEGRATED SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT PLAN (ISWMP) AND IMPLEMENTING THE NEW INTEGRATED SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT PLAN (ISWMP) WHICH WILL BE CONDUCTED BY THE GRANTEE WILL BENEFIT THE CONFEDERATED TRIBES OF THE COOS, LOWER UMPQUA AND SIUSLAW INDIAN COMMUNITY (CTCLUSI). THIS WILL ADDRESS ADDRESS THE EXPANDED COMMUNITY GROWTH, NEW BUSINESSES AND FACILITIES THAT GREW AS A RESULT OF 15,000 ACRES OF REACQUIRED LAND WHICH THE FORMER 2013 ISWMP IS INADEQUATE TO ADDRESS. CTCLUSI ALSO INTENDS TO CONDUCT COMMUNITY EDUCATION AND OUTREACH AS WELL AS TRAIN SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT STAFF. ALL OF THESE ENDEAVORS WILL IMPROVE HUMAN HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENTAL SAFETY IN THE CTCLUSI COMMUNITY. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, THERE IS THE POTENTIAL BENEFIT TO MANY OTHER TRIBAL COMMUNITIES AS THE GRANTEE HAS COMMITTED TO SHARING THE NEW ISWMP AND PROJECT SUMMARY THAT DESCRIBES CHALLENGES, SUCCESSES AND WILL CONTAIN USEFUL TOOLS, AND HELPFUL CONTACTS. THIS INFORMATION WILL BE SHARED VIA THE EPA REGION 10 TRIBAL LISTERV, EPA REGION 10 BROWNFIELDS LISTSERV, THE WEST COAST OCEAN ALLIANCE, THE OREGON TRIBAL PREPAREDNESS COALITION, AND OTHER FORUMS AND HAS THE POTENTIAL TO BENEFIT LOCAL OREGON TRIBAL COMMUNITIES AS WELL AS THOSE ACROSS THE NATION.

DESCRIPTION:FOOD LIFELINE (GRANT LEAD) WILL PARTNER WITH DUWAMISH VALLEY SUSTAINABILITY ASSOCIATION, BLACK STAR FARMERS, AND SUSTAINABLE SEATTLE TO DEVELOP AN ANAEROBIC DIGESTION DEMONSTRATION PROJECT THAT INTRODUCES BLACK, INDIGENOUS, PEOPLE OF COLOR (BIPOC) LOCATED IN THE SOUTH PARK COMMUNITY OF SEATTLE TO THE FOOD TO WASTE TO SOIL TO FOOD CYCLE AND THE POTENTIAL FOR ALTERNATIVE ENERGY PRODUCTION THROUGH HANDS-ON, CULTURALLY AND LINGUISTICALLY RELEVANT ENGAGEMENT AND EDUCATION OPPORTUNITIES. OUR SOUTH CITY BIODIGESTER COLLABORATION PROJECT WILL BE COMMUNITY OWNED AND CONTROLLED PROVIDING BIPOC AND LOW-INCOME COMMUNITIES AUTONOMY OVER THEIR WASTE TO ENERGY CYCLE AT THE HYPER LOCAL LEVEL, REDUCING RELIANCE ON CONTAMINATED COMPOST MATERIAL, REDUCING GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS AND INTRODUCING IMMIGRANT AND FIRST-GENERATION YOUTH TO STEM CAREER PATHWAYS. ACTIVITIES:FOOD LIFELINE, DUWAMISH VALLEY SUSTAINABILITY ASSOCIATION (DVSA), BLACK STAR FARMERS (BSF), AND SUSTAINABLE SEATTLE (S2) WILL PARTNER TO DELIVER AN ANAEROBIC DIGESTION DEMONSTRATION PROJECT, KNOWN AS THE SOUTH CITY BIODIGESTER COLLABORATION (SCBC), IN THE SOUTH PARK NEIGHBORHOOD OF SEATTLE, WA. THE SCBC WILL DEVELOP NEW AD CAPACITY FOR PROCESSING FOOD WASTE AND DEMONSTRATE SOLUTIONS AND/OR APPROACHES FOR INCREASING FOOD WASTE AD UTILIZATION THAT CAN BE REPLICATED BY OTHER COMMUNITIES, GOVERNMENTS, OR OTHER ENTITIES. THIS PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO BE AN INITIAL EXHIBITION DEMONSTRATING THE POTENTIAL FOR A LARGER SCALE BIOFUEL SYSTEM AND ACTING AS AN EXAMPLE OF A CLOSED LOOP 'CIRCULAR ECONOMY.' PARTNERS WILL WORK WITH LOCAL STAKEHOLDERS TO BENEFIT THE LOCAL COMMUNITY. THE DEMONSTRATION PROJECT WILL INTRODUCE AND INCREASE KNOWLEDGE FOR BLACK, INDIGENOUS, AND PEOPLE OF COLOR (BIPOC) IN THE SOUTH PARK COMMUNITY ON THE BENEFITS OF ANAEROBIC DIGESTION (AD), CLEAN COMPOST, AND A COMMUNITY CONTROLLED CIRCULAR ECONOMY, WHILE INTRODUCING BIPOC YOUTH IN THE DUWAMISH VALLEY TO NEW TECHNICAL AND/OR PROFESSIONAL SPECIALTIES. SUBRECIPIENT:THESE ACTIVITIES WILL BE CONDUCTED BY PROJECT PARTNERS:

DUWAMISH VALLEY SUSTAINABILITY ASSOCIATION WILL PROVIDE THE TECHNICAL EXPERTISE, YOUTH AND COMMUNITY NETWORK ENGAGEMENT, AND WORKSHOPS AND COMMUNITY EDUCATION EVENTS AND UP TO 200 HOURS OF \CURRICULUM. 

BLACK STAR FARMERS WILL PROVIDE TECHNICAL EXPERTISE, A BLACK AND INDIGENOUS FARMER NETWORK, UTILIZE AND DEMONSTRATE CO-PRODUCT USE, IDENTIFY OTHER BIPOC FARMS IN NEED OF EXCESS CO-PRODUCT, AND PROVIDE UP TO 200 HOURS OF CURRICULUM

SUSTAINABLE SEATTLE WILL PROVIDE PROGRAM OVERSIGHT THROUGH UP TO 100 HOURS RELATIONSHIP AND PROJECT MANAGEMENT SUPPORT. S2 WILL ALSO PROMOTE CLASSES AND DISTRIBUTE INFORMATION ABOUT THE PROJECT TO THEIR WIDE NETWORK. 
OUTCOMES:THE SCBC PROJECT WILL BE AN INITIAL EXHIBITION OF A NEW TECHNOLOGY PROCESS FOR THE SOUTH PARK COMMUNITY, LEVERAGING BREAKTHROUGH TECHNOLOGY THAT INVOLVES THE AD PROCESS COUPLED WITH VERY LOW ENERGY INPUTS MAKING IT MORE ACCESSIBLE FOR SMALL SCALE BUSINESSES AND ORGANIZATIONS. THE  PROJECT WILL EVALUATE THE COST EFFECTIVENESS OF INPUTS AND OUTPUT POTENTIALS FOR SCALABILITY IN SMALL BUSINESS AND COMMUNITY USE, LEVERAGE ITS FINDINGS AND IMPACT TO ASSESS THE TECHNOLOGICAL FEASIBILITY AND COST EFFECTIVENESS OF A LARGER SCALE BIOFUEL SYSTEM IN THE SOUTH PARK COMMUNITY, AND UTILIZE A NEW INNOVATION IN ORGANICS CONVERSION BY DEVELOPING A LOCAL, COMMUNITY BASED, BIPOC LED FARM-TO TABLE AND BACK-TO-FARM LIFE CYCLE.
THE DEMONSTRATION PROJECT WILL MEASURE SPECIFIC AD DELIVERABLES INCLUDING: POUNDS OF WASTE DIVERTED FROM LANDFILLS AND LARGE COMPOSTING FACILITIES, NUMBER OF GALLONS OF DIGESTATES UTILIZED BY BSF IN THEIR LOCAL FARMS, AMOUNT OF COMMUNITY PARTICIPATION AND YOUTH INVOLVEMENT, AND NUMBER OF EDUCATION AND ENGAGEMENT EVENTS HELD.

DESCRIPTION:THE WORK CONDUCTED USING THIS GRANT FUNDING WILL BE INSTRUMENTAL IN FURTHER STRENGTHENING AND ADVANCING THE UNITED KEETOOWAH BAND OF CHEROKEE INDIANS IN OKLAHOMA'S (UKB'S) SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM. THIS PROJECT WILL BE TO IMPLEMENT AND PROVIDED BETTER RESOURCES FOR OUR TRIBAL MEMBERS TO PROPERLY DISPOSE OF SOLID WASTE AND PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO PROPERLY REMEDIATE ILLEGAL DUMPSITES ON TRIBAL LANDS. THIS STUDY IS CRUCIAL TO PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT BECAUSE IT PROVIDES A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE RECYCLING HABITS OF THE TRIBAL COMMUNITY. DEVELOP A THOROUGH MORE CONCISE EDUCATION PROGRAM. THIS WILL ALLOW THE TRIBE TO CONTINUE TO DEVELOP ITS SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM IN A COHESIVE, STRATEGIC, AND LOGICAL MANNER AND IMPROVE SUCCESS FOR PROGRAM LONGEVITY. THIS GRANT WILL ASSIST THE TRIBE IN INITIATING A PROGRAM TO ALLOW THE SOLID WASTE PROGRAM TO BE CONDUCTED IN A MORE SUSTAINABLE MANNER, INCLUDING RECYCLING, DIVERSION, AND UNDERSTANDING OF WASTE STREAM. AS A RESULT, NATURAL RESOURCES ARE PROTECTED WITH THE EFFECT THAT TRIBAL MEMBER'S JOBS ARE MAINTAINED OR CREATED, AND TRIBAL REVENUES IMPROVE. THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $100,000. ACTIVITIES:UKB WILL CONDUCT WASTE COMPOSITION STUDIES TO EVALUATE THE SIGNIFICANCE OF THE CURRENT WASTE STREAM. THIS PROJECT WILL BE TO IMPLEMENT AND PROVIDED BETTER RESOURCES FOR OUR TRIBAL MEMBERS TO PROPERLY DISPOSE OF SOLID WASTE AND PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO PROPERLY REMEDIATE ILLEGAL DUMPSITES ON TRIBAL LANDS. THE TRIBE WILL CONDUCT QUARTERLY WASTE STREAM ANALYSIS OF CURRENT TRIBAL HUB AND SPOKE PROGRAM. THE STUDY WILL FOCUS ON THE HABITS OF RESIDENTIAL CUSTOMERS UTILIZING TRIBAL RECYCLING TRAILERS AS THEIR PRIMARY SOURCE FOR RECYCLING. ALSO, THE TRIBE WILL CONDUCT MARKET RESEARCH ON ITEMS NOT ACCEPTED WITH CURRENT RECYCLING DROP-OFF PROGRAM. A SUMMARY REPORT WILL BE CONDUCTED ON ITEMS DROPPED OFF FOR RECYCLING AT THESE LOCATIONS ONLY. LASTLY, UKB WILL PROVIDE PROJECT FINDINGS, CONCLUSIONS, AND RECOMMENDATIONS FOR FUTURE ACTIVITIES.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE RESULTS FROM RESIDENTIAL AND TRIBAL MEMBERS WASTE STREAM DATA COLLECTION, RECYCLING FINDINGS COLLECTED FROM ILLEGAL DUMPSITES, UPDATED INTEGRATED WASTE MANAGEMENT PLAN, AND A FINAL REPORT THAT PRESENTS THE FINDINGS OF THE PROJECT AND INCLUDES AN EVALUATION OF POTENTIAL SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT ALTERNATIVES SUCH AS RECYCLING, DIVERSION, AND IDENTIFY OPTIONS TO MINIMIZE CONTAMINATION THROUGH UTILIZATION OF PROPER DISPOSAL OF SOLID WASTE. THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES ARE THAT THIS PROJECT WILL HAVE SIGNIFICANT POSITIVE IMPACTS TO OVERALL COMMUNITY HEALTH AND REDUCTION OF THREATS TO HUMAN HEALTH AND THE ENVIRONMENT. THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE A FIRST STEP IN UNDERSTANDING HOW TO BETTER MANAGE RECYCLING PROCEDURES USING PROPER DISPOSAL OF SOLID WASTE ON TRIBAL LANDS GATHERED ON ILLEGAL DUMPSITES. THESE WASTES ARE KNOWN TO CONTRIBUTE TO TOXIC AND HAZARDOUS CHEMICAL RELEASES INTO THE SOIL AND EVENTUALLY INFILTRATE INTO GROUNDWATER OR BE RELEASED TO THE ATMOSPHERE. ADDITIONALLY, THE GRANT WILL BE USED TO ADDRESS THE IMMEDIATE AND CHRONIC THREATS TO THE TRIBE'S TOURISM AND RECREATION SECTORS THAT RESULT FROM INEFFECTIVE SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT. BY IDENTIFYING AND IMPLEMENTING OPPORTUNITIES FOR INCREASED RECYCLING AND WASTE DIVERSION, THE WASTE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM CAN BE MORE COST EFFECTIVE. THROUGH TRIBE'S IMPLEMENTATION OF RECYCLING TOXIC WASTE, IT REDUCES THE CONTAMINATION OF THE WASTE STREAM TO THE PUBLIC HEALTH OF THE COMMUNITY. THIS GRANT WILL HELP ELIMINATE PUBLIC HEALTH RISKS CAUSED BY CONTAMINATED WASTE, AND IT WILL ALLOW THE TRIBE TO FULLY STUDY THE IMPORTANCE OF RECYCLING WASTE. TOXIC WASTE AND NON-RECYCLING CAN BE A MAJOR THREAT TO THE TRIBE'S EARNINGS.
