DESCRIPTION:THIS ACTION APPROVES AN AWARD IN THE AMOUNT OF $25,000 TO TRULY LIVING WELL TO CONDUCT AN EXPANSION OF FOOD WASTE AWARENESS TO RESTAURANTS: IN COLLABORATION WITH THE COMMUNITY COMPOST PROJECT AT TRULY LIVING WELL (TLW), THE CITY OF ATLANTA (COA) PLANNING DEPARTMENT WILL INTRODUCE FOOD WASTE PREVENTION MEASURES INTO THE COA'S PERMITTING OF FOOD BUSINESSES..ACTIVITIES:AS PART OF THEIR 'NEW BUSINESS PROCESS ROADMAPS AND CHECKLISTS,' TLW AND COA PLANNING DEPARTMENT WILL DEVELOP AND PROVIDE THE FOLLOWING INFORMATION:   DEMONSTRATE HOW TO PURCHASE SURPLUS PRODUCE FROM COA'S FARM FOOD LOSS PROGRAM (AND LOCAL URBAN AGLANTA PRODUCERS),  DEMONSTRATE HOW TO RECOVER/DONATE EDIBLE SURPLUS FOOD AND HOW TO COMPOST THE USED FOODS.
 THIS PROCESS IS BEING DEVELOPED TO HELP TACKLE SOME OF THE MOST PRESSING CHALLENGES OF OUR CURRENT FOOD SYSTEM AND TO CONNECT LOCAL FOOD PARTNERS, INCLUDING GROWERS, DISTRIBUTORS, COMPOSTERS, AND MORE.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:THIS PROJECT WILL SOLIDIFY A CIRCULAR, ECONOMICALLY AND ENVIRONMENTALLY SUSTAINABLE MODEL THAT SUPPORTS A HEALTHY AND RESILIENT LOCAL FOOD SYSTEM - REDUCING FOOD WASTE AND IMPROVING FOOD SECURITY WHILE BENEFITTING GROWERS, DISTRIBUTORS, AND CONSUMERS.  THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT ARE THE FOOD SERVICE BUSINESSES AND COMMUNITIES IN AND AROUND ATLANTA.

DESCRIPTION:THIS ACTION APPROVES AN AWARD IN THE AMOUNT OF $200,000 TO GEORGIA SOUTHERN RESEARCH AND SERVICE FOUNDATION.  THE PROJECT WILL ADVANCE THE UNDERSTANDING OF HOW EXISTING ANAEROBIC DIGESTION (AD) CAPACITY AT PULP AND PAPER MILLS CAN BE SUSTAINABLY LEVERAGED FOR THE TREATMENT OF FOOD WASTE FROM UNIVERSITY CAMPUSES. THIS RESEARCH WILL INTEGRATE EXPERIMENTATION, QUANTITATIVE SUSTAINABLE DESIGN, AND COMMUNITY-ENGAGED RESEARCH. THIS FRAMEWORK WILL BE USED TO DEMONSTRATE HOW FOOD WASTE CAN BE DIVERTED FROM LANDFILLS, WHILE POTENTIALLY PROVIDING PAPER MILLS WITH THE OPPORTUNITY TO ENRICH THEIR SLUDGE FOR BETTER DIGESTION AND INCREASED BIOGAS PRODUCTION.ACTIVITIES:THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL ADVANCE THE UNDERSTANDING OF HOW EXISTING ANAEROBIC DIGESTION (AD) CAPACITY AT PULP AND PAPER MILLS CAN BE SUSTAINABLY LEVERAGED FOR THE TREATMENT OF
FOOD WASTE FROM UNIVERSITY CAMPUSES. THIS RESEARCH WILL INTEGRATE EXPERIMENTATION, QUANTITATIVE SUSTAINABLE DESIGN (QSD), AND COMMUNITY-ENGAGED RESEARCH. THIS FRAMEWORK WILL BE USED TO DEMONSTRATE HOW FOOD WASTE CAN BE DIVERTED FROM LANDFILLS, WHILE PROVIDING PAPER MILLS WITH THE OPPORTUNITY TO ENRICH THEIR SLUDGE FOR BETTER DIGESTION AND INCREASED BIOGAS PRODUCTION. THIS APPROACH ALSO COULD POTENTIALLY SUPPORT PAPER MILLS WITH COST-EFFECTIVE ENERGY PRODUCTION BY ADVANCING THEIR EXISTING AD CAPACITY WITH INCREASED BIOGAS PRODUCTION. FIRST, BENCH-TOP AD STUDIES WILL ASSESS FEASIBILITY (CONSIDERING CO-DIGESTION RATIOS) BY TRACKING TREATMENT EFFICIENCIES, BIOGAS PRODUCTION, AND MICROBIAL COMMUNITIES. COLLEGE STUDENTS, PRIMARILY FROM LOW SOCIOECONOMIC HOUSEHOLDS, WILL CONTRIBUTE TO DATA COLLECTION ON TYPES OF FOOD WASTE CREATED ON CAMPUS AND LOCAL RESTAURANTS. NEXT, DATA FROM EXPERIMENTAL AND COMMUNITY ENGAGED RESEARCH WILL BE INTEGRATED INTO A QSD METHODOLOGY (INCLUDING TECHNO-ECONOMIC ANALYSIS (TEA) AND LIFE CYCLE ASSESSMENT (LCA) PAIRED WITH UNCERTAINTY AND SENSITIVITY ANALYSIS) ACROSS A LANDSCAPE OF SCENARIOS (COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, TREATMENT) TO ASSESS SUSTAINABILITY. THIS PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL CHART A PATH FORWARD FOR SUPPORTING AND IMPROVING AD IN COMMUNITIES AND DEVELOP SUSTAINABLE EFFORTS TO REDUCE THE AMOUNT OF FOOD WASTE FROM COLLEGE TOWNS THAT IS DISPOSED OF IN LANDFILLS.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP SUSTAINABLE PRACTICES FOR CO-DIGESTION OF FOOD WASTE AND PAPER MILL SLUDGE LEVERAGING EXISTING AD INFRASTRUCTURE. RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE (I) A FUNDAMENTAL UNDERSTANDING OF THE IMPACT OF AD FEEDSTOCK MIXTURE RATIOS (FOOD WASTE AND PAPER MILL SLUDGE) TO DEVELOP OPERATING PROCEDURE INFORMED BY DATA ON MICROBIAL COMMUNITIES, BIOGAS PRODUCTION, AND REDUCTION OF VOLATILE SOLIDS; (II) COST AND GHG EMISSIONS OF AD ACROSS THREE COMPARATIVE SCENARIOS AS WELL AS MODELING OF SPECIFIC OUTPUTS (E.G., BIOGAS PRODUCTION, DOLLARS SAVED, POUNDS OF SOIL AMENDMENT PRODUCED); AND (III) DATA ON THE TYPE OF FOOD WASTE GENERATED BY THE UNIVERSITY AND LOCAL BUSINESSES (I.E., POUNDS OF FOOD WASTE THAT CAN BE DIVERTED FROM LANDFILLS). THE QUANTITATIVE RESULTS OF THIS WORK CAN BE USED TO FACILITATE THE ADOPTION OF THIS NOVEL APPROACH IN THE CASE STUDY AREA WITH THE POTENTIAL FOR EXPANSION ACROSS THE U.S. DEVELOPING A SYNERGY BETWEEN INDUSTRY (PAPER MILLS) AND COMMUNITIES (UNIVERSITIES AND BUSINESSES) PROVIDES AN OPTION TO THE SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT OF FOOD WASTE THAT WILL BE DIRECTLY LINKED TO ENVIRONMENTAL IMPROVEMENT. THE OUTPUTS INCLUDE OPERATING PROCEDURES FOR AD FEEDSTOCK MIXTURE RATIOS AND DETAILED EVALUATION OF THIS DEMONSTRATION WITH BIOGAS PRODUCED AND ITS POTENTIAL AS HEAT AND ENERGY, DOLLARS SAVED BY ENRICHING PAPER MILL SLUDGE WITH FOOD WASTE, AND POUNDS OF SOIL AMENDMENT PRODUCED. THE OUTPUT OF THE COMMUNITY-ENGAGED WORK WILL BE THE POTENTIAL POUNDS OF FOOD WASTE DIVERTED TO AD FROM THE UNIVERSITY AND BUSINESSES. OVERALL, THE OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE GENERATING NEW KNOWLEDGE THROUGH EXPLORING THE FEAS

DESCRIPTION:THIS ACTION APPROVES AN AWARD IN THE AMOUNT OF $25,000 TO LIVE-THRIVE, INCORPORATED TO SUPPORT THEIR OPENING OF A SECOND CENTER FOR HARD TO RECYCLE MATERIALS (CHARM) SITE IN DEKALB COUNTY. LIVE THRIVE WILL CONTINUE TO OFFER ITS RECYCLING SERVICES FOR HARD TO RECYCLE MATERIALS AND HOUSEHOLD HAZARDOUS WASTE AT THE EXPANDED CHARM DEKALB SITE AND ADDITIONALLY, WILL INCLUDE EXPANDED EDUCATIONAL SERVICES AND OPPORTUNITIES.

ACTIVITIES:ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THIS AWARD WILL PROVIDE FUNDING TOWARDS THE PURCHASE OF A FORKLIFT TO MOVE AND MANAGE MATERIALS BROUGHT TO THE CHARM DEKALB FACILITY, PRINTING OF PERMANENT 25 SIGNS IN THE FACILITY DESCRIBING THE MATERIALS ACCEPTED IN EACH RECYCLING STATION AND OTHER SIGNAGE DESCRIBING SUSTAINABILITY PRACTICES GENERALLY, EDUCATIONAL AND PROMOTIONAL MATERIALS TO INCREASE USAGE OF LIVE THRIVE'S RECYCLING FACILITY, AND CONTRACTUAL FUNDS FOR A MATERIALS PROCESSING VENDOR TO RESPONSIBLY DISPOSE CHEMICALS AND PAINT. APPROXIMATELY 75% FUNDING TOWARDS PURCHASE OF A FORKLIFT TO MOVE AND MANAGE MATERIALS BROUGHT TO THE CHARM DEKALB FACILITY.

DESCRIPTION:THIS ACTION APPROVES AN AWARD IN THE AMOUNT OF $50,000 TO THE LAND OF SKY TO SUPPORT A NEW DON'T WASTE FOOD NORTH CAROLINA CAMPAIGN THROUGH THE CREATION OF TRANSFERABLE RESOURCE TOOLS, SELF-ASSESSMENT GUIDANCE AND ON-SITE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROVIDED BY AN INNOVATIVE STATEWIDE TEAM OF BUSINESS PROFESSIONALS ACTIVITIES:ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: 1) ONE-ON-ONE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO COMMERCIAL AND INSTITUTIONAL FOOD SERVICE SECTORS; 2) DEVELOPMENT OF TRANSFERRABLE RESOURCES AND 3) SUPPORTING NC DEQ AND OTHER STATES PARTNERS SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:ANTICIPATED PROJECT DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTPUTS AND OUTCOMES INCLUDE NUMBER OF CLIENTS INTRODUCED TO EPA, NUMBER OF NEW FOOD EFFICIENCY METHODS PUT INTO PRACTICE, NUMBER OF OF NEW TRANSFERABLE RESOURCES DEVELOPED, A NEW DON'T WASTE FOOD NC WEBSITE, NUMBER OF SOCIAL MEDIA POSTS AND NUMBER OF OUTREACH WEBINARS. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE COMMERCIAL FOOD SERVICE PROVIDERS AND VARIOUS STAKEHOLDERS AFFILIATED WITH NC FOOD WASTE CAMPAIGN.

DESCRIPTION:
THIS ACTION APPROVES AN AWARD IN THE AMOUNT OF $100,000 TO 4 ROOTS FOUNDATION, INC. THE 4ROOTS SUSTAINABLE FOOD SYSTEM NETWORK IS BEING DEVELOPED TO TACKLE SOME OF THE MOST PRESSING CHALLENGES OF OUR CURRENT FOOD SYSTEM BY APPOINTING A NETWORK MANAGER TO BUILD A HYPER-CONNECTED NETWORK OF LOCAL FOOD PARTNERS, INCLUDING GROWERS, DISTRIBUTORS, COMPOSTERS, AND MORE.  

ACTIVITIES:
THIS PROJECT WILL FOSTER COLLABORATION THAT GENERATES GREATER ECONOMIC EFFICIENCIES TO REDUCE FOOD WASTE AND IMPROVE FOOD SECURITY. IT WILL ALLOW FOR ESTABLISHING NEW DISTRIBUTION CHANNELS THAT MOVE MORE LOCALLY-GROWN NUTRIENT-DENSE PRODUCE TO BOTH SALES AND DONATION OUTLETS THROUGHOUT THE COMMUNITY, ENSURING THAT MORE LOCAL PRODUCE IS ACTUALLY HARVESTED AND DISTRIBUTED TO LOCAL CONSUMERS, RATHER THAN GOING TO WASTE IN THE FIELDS OR LANDFILLS.  ANY FOOD THAT IS NOT FIT FOR CONSUMPTION WILL BE COMPOSTED TO CREATE RICH NATURAL SOIL AMENDMENTS, WHICH WILL BE PROVIDED BACK TO THE LOCAL FARMERS. 
OUTCOMES:
THIS PROJECT WILL SOLIDIFY AN ECONOMICALLY AND ENVIRONMENTALLY SUSTAINABLE MODEL THAT SUPPORTS A HEALTHY AND RESILIENT LOCAL FOOD SYSTEM - REDUCING FOOD WASTE AND IMPROVING FOOD SECURITY WHILE BENEFITTING GROWERS, DISTRIBUTORS, AND CONSUMERS, AND IT WILL ALLOW FOR FUTURE REPLICATION ACROSS THE REGION. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT ARE THE VULNERABLE COMMUNITIES IN AND AROUND ATLANTA.
 

SUBRECIPIENT:
NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.

DESCRIPTION:
THIS ACTION APPROVES AN AWARD IN THE AMOUNT OF $75,269 TO THE UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA RESEARCH FOUNDATION TO CONDUCT A CIRCULARITY ASSESSMENT PROTOCOL (CAP) IN THREE RURAL COMMUNITIES IN REGION 4, AND WORK WITH THESE THREE COMMUNITIES TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT INTERVENTION STRATEGIES THAT IMPROVE THE RESILIENCE OF THE RURAL RECYCLING SYSTEMS. THE THREE COMMUNITIES ARE TIFT COUNTY, GEORGIA; CHEROKEE COUNTY, NORTH CAROLINA, AND THE EASTERN BAND OF CHEROKEE INDIANS; AND GEORGETOWN COUNTY, SOUTH CAROLINA. 
ACTIVITIES:
ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:  COLLABORATIVELY CONDUCT THE CIRCULARITY ASSESSMENT PROTOCOL (CAP) FOCUSED ON RECYCLING IN THREE DIVERSE RURAL AREAS IN REGION 4.  THE CAP WILL ALSO PRODUCE ADDITIONAL MAPPING OF WHERE THE VARIOUS RECYCLABLE MATERIALS ARE GOING (IF RECYCLING OCCURS) IN THOSE AREAS.  HOST WORKSHOPS IN EACH COMMUNITY TO DISCUSS THE FINDINGS WITH STAKEHOLDERS TO FACILITATE DISCUSSIONS BETWEEN THE THREE AREAS.   
OUTCOMES:
ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE PHASE I (PRE-FIELD ANALYSIS) OUTPUTS INCLUDE A LITERATURE REVIEW, FIELDWORK PLAN, TRANSECT SAMPLING MAPS, AND INITIAL STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT AND INTERVIEWS. PHASE 1 OUTCOMES INCLUDE ENGAGING THE COMMUNITIES SO THEY FEEL OWNERSHIP OF THE PROCESS AND DATA. PHASE II (FIELDWORK) OUTPUTS INCLUDE FIELD CAP DATA,  PHASE II OUTCOMES INCLUDE COMMUNITY COLLABORATION AND INCREASED AWARENESS OF WASTE MANAGEMENT, RECYCLING, AND LITTER.  PHASE III OUTCOMES INCLUDE AN UNDERSTANDING OF HOW DATA CAN INFORM INTERVENTIONS TO INCREASE CIRCULARITY, RECYCLING AND SUSTAINABILITY.  PHASE IV OUTCOMES INCLUDE THAT THE COMMUNITIES WILL UNDERSTAND THEIR ROLE AS A SYSTEM, IN A LARGER REGIONAL SYSTEM, HOW THEY CAN BE EMPOWERED TO CHANGE SYSTEMS, AND IMPROVE COMMUNITY SECURITY AND RESILIENCE. 
	
THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE PEOPLE OF IN AND AROUND THE SELECTED THREE COMMUNITIES ALONG WITH THE RECYCLING SYSTEMS IN THOSE STATES.
SUBRECIPIENT:
$5,000 TO EACH OF THE THREE COUNTIES (TOTAL OF $15,000 IN SUBAWARDS) WILL BE PROVIDED DIRECTLY TO FUND ELIGIBLE INTERVENTIONS THAT ARE IDENTIFIED IN THE STAKEHOLDER WORKSHOP FOLLOWING THE FINAL CIRCULARITY ASSESSMENT PROTOCOL (CAP) REPORT. EXAMPLES OF INTERVENTIONS MAY INCLUDE INCREASED SIGNAGE ON PUBLIC WASTE RECEPTACLES.

THIS ACTION APPROVES AN AWARD IN THE AMOUNT OF $25,000 TO SUPPORT THE SOUTHEAST RECYCLING DEVELOPMENT COUNCIL (SERDC) IN THEIR EFFORTS TO EXPLORE THE AVAILABILITY AND EFFECTIVENESS OF RECYCLING ACCESS IN RURAL AREAS ACROSS THE SOUTHEAST. THE PROJECT WILL GATHER DATA AT THE COUNTY LEVEL THE EFFECTIVENESS WILL BE DETERMINED BY THE POUNDS PER HOUSEHOLD RECYCLED ANNUALLY. ONCE THE DATA COLLECTION IS COMPLETED, THE RESULTS WILL BE PRESENTED GRAPHICALLY ON AN INTERACTIVE MAPPING TOOL. SERDC WILL OVERLAY THE MAP WITH THE LOCATIONS OF THE MATERIAL RECOVERY FACILITIES (MRFS) IN THE REGION. SUBJECTIVE EVALUATION OF THE RESULTING MAP WILL ALLOW THE USER TO DETERMINE AREAS WHERE POOR MATERIAL RECOVERY COULD BE IMPROVED BY BETTER ACCESS TO MRFS. THE PROJECT WILL PRODUCE A LIST OF MULTICOUNTY REGIONS WHERE RECYCLING PERFORMANCE IS BELOW AVERAGE AND THE PROXIMITY TO MRF INFRASTRUCTURE IS LACKING. THE OUTPUT WILL BE PUBLICATION OF THE FINDINGS, INCLUDING GEOGRAPHICAL PRESENTATION OF RURAL RECYCLING PR

THIS ACTION APPROVES AN AWARD IN THE AMOUNT OF $25,000 TO NORTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY TO UPGRADE THE NORTH CAROLINA RECYCLING MARKETS DIRECTORY (RMD). THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE PEOPLE OF NORTH CAROLINA ALONG WITH THE RECYCLING INDUSTRY IN THE STATE.  THIS GRANT WILL ALLOW NORTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY TO FIND AND DEVELOP A SOLUTION AND SUPPORT THE UPGRADE OF THE APPLICATIONS THAT OPERATE THIS IMPORTANT TOOL. ADDITIONALLY, STAFF HAVE IDENTIFIED A SERIES OF DESIRED UPGRADES TO IMPROVE THE FUNCTIONALITY AND USER INTERFACE OF THE TOOL. SOME OF THESE INCLUDE: INCORPORATING A MAPPING FEATURE TO VIEW COMPANIES OR SEARCH RESULTS GEOGRAPHICALLYAND ADDING FILTERING OPTIONS TO REFINE RESULTS BASED ON COMPANY SERVICES (E.G., HAULING, PROCESSING, BROKERING)AND IMPROVING THE FUNCTIONALITY OF THE TOOL ON MOBILE DEVICESAND AND MODERNIZING THE LOOK AND FEEL OF THE TOOL TO GIVE NEW AND RETURNING USERS THE IMPRESSION OF A WELL-MAINTAINED DIRECTORY AND BOOST THE CREDIBILITY OF THE INFORMATION CONTAINED WITHIN.

THIS ACTION APPROVES AN AWARD IN THE AMOUNT OF $25,000 TO UNITED AGAINST POVERTY TO HELP PILOT A PROGRAM TO CONNECT LOCAL FARMERS/GLEANERS WITH UNITED AGAINST POVERTYS MOBILE MARKET PROGRAM. UNITED AGAINST POVERTY WILL DEMONSTRATE PRODUCE CAN BE RESCUED FROM FIELDS, TRANSPORTED EFFICIENTLY, AND DELIVERED IN A SUSTAINABLE WAY. THE PILOT PROGRAM ACTIVITIES WILL HELP PROVIDE SURPLUS PRODUCE TO COMMUNITIES IN GREAT NEED, PROVIDE AN ALTERNATIVE TO FOOD WASTE AT THE FARM LEVEL, AND CREATE A SUSTAINABLE FOOD ACCESS POINT THAT CAN BE REPLICATED WITH RELIABLE FREQUENCY.

THIS ACTION APPROVES AN AWARD IN THE AMOUNT OF $25,000 TO THE 4R FOUNDATION INC. TO HELP SUPPORT THEIR EFFORTS WITH REDIRECTING FARM SURPLUS AND HELPING COMMUNITIES IN GREAT NEED BY PROVIDING AN ALTERNATIVE TO FOOD WASTE. NOTE THAT THE HEADER OF THIS AWARD CAPTIONS IT AS A GRANT AGREEMENT WHEREAS IT IS A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT. EPA IS IMPLEMENTING A NEW GRANT SYSTEM THAT WILL SOON BE UNDERGOING ENHANCEMENTS TO ALLOW FOR MORE ACCURATE DESCRIPTIONS.

THIS ACTION APPROVES AN AWARD IN THE AMOUNT OF $25,000 TO THE GREEN LUNCH BOX FOR THE ASSOCIATION OF GLEANING ORGANIZATIONS (AGO)  TRAINING PROJECT TO INCREASE THE CAPACITY OF GLEANING ORGANIZATIONS ACROSS THE COUNTRY SO THEY CAN BETTER ENGAGE COMMUNITIES TO HARVEST SURPLUS PRODUCE. IN TURN, VULNERABLE POPULATIONS ARE PROVIDED WITH INCREASED ACCESS TO WHOLESOME FOODS. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO OFFER TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO AGO MEMBER GLEANERS ON THE TOPICS OF LABOR LAW, 501 C3. LIABILITY, VOLUNTEER MANAGEMENT, FUNDRASING, DATABASE MANAGEMENT, STRATEGIC PLANNING, PROGRAM EVALUATION, AND SOCIAL MEDIA MARKETING.

THIS ACTION APPROVES AN AWARD IN THE AMOUNT OF $298,502 TO EMORY UNIVERSITY TO ESTABLISH A PROTOTYPE FOR ANAEROBIC DIGESTION OF FOOD WASTE IN AN URBAN AREA WITHIN ATLANTA, GEORGIA, TO PRODUCE RENEWABLE BIOGAS AND SOIL AMENDMENTS. EMORY WILL PARTNER WITH THE CITY OF ATLANTA AND OTHER SURROUNDING MUNICIPALITIES TO FURTHER SCALE UP TO ADDRESS METRO ATLANTA'S FOOD WASTE AND RENEWABLE ENERGY CHALLENGES AS WELL AS THOSE ACROSS THE COUNTRY.  THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES EPA'S SEARCH FOR PROPOSALS TO ACCELERATE THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEW AND/OR ENHANCED ANAEROBIC DIGESTION CAPACITY AND INFRASTRUCTURE IN THE UNITED STATES. NOTE THAT THE HEADER OF THIS AWARD CAPTIONS IT AS A GRANT AGREEMENT WHEREAS IT IS A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT. EPA IS IMPLEMENTING A NEW GRANT SYSTEM THAT WILL SOON BE UNDERGOING ENHANCEMENTS TO ALLOW FOR MORE ACCURATE DESCRIPTIONS.

THIS ACTION APPROVES AN AWARD IN THE AMOUNT OF 195,426 TO FLORIDA ATLANTIC UNIVERSITY TO SUPPORT THEIR EFFORTS WITH DEVELOPING THE SCIENCE NEEDED TO BUILD THE FOUNDATION OF A REGIONAL ORGANICS DIVERSION MODEL THAT TAKES ADVANTAGE OF EXCESS DIGESTER CAPACITY AT LOCAL WASTEWATER TREATMENT FACILITIES. FLORIDA ATLANTIC UNIVERSITY WILL MEASURE KEY ORGANIC WASTE PROPERTIES AND RUN LABORATORY SCALE EXPERIMENTS TO DEVELOP ENGINEERING DESIGN PARAMETERS THAT CAN EVENTUALLY BE USED IN FULL SCALE PROJECTS. FLORIDA ATLANTIC UNIVERSITY WILL ALSO EVALUATE SCENARIOS TO SIMULATE AND PREDICT THE ENVIRONMENTAL AND ECONOMIC IMPACTS OF A REPLICABLE ORGANIC WASTE DIVERSION MODEL UTILIZING EXISTING REGIONAL ANAEROBIC DIGESTION CAPACITY. 'NOTE THAT THE HEADER OF THIS AWARD CAPTIONS IT AS A GRANT AGREEMENT WHEREAS IT IS A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT. EPA IS IMPLEMENTING A NEW GRANT SYSTEM THAT WILL SOON BE UNDERGOING ENHANCEMENTS TO ALLOW FOR MORE ACCURATE DESCRIPTIONS.'

WASHINGTON STATE UNIVERSITY (WSU) WILL LEVERAGE RESEARCH AND DATA DERIVED FROM PARTNERSHIPS WITH OTHER STATE INSTITUTIONS (WASHINGTON STATE DEPARTMENTS OF COMMERCE AND ECOLOGY) TO IDENTIFY THREE OPTIMAL AREAS IN WASHINGTON STATE FOR DEVELOPING SUCCESSFUL, MULTI-PARTNER DIGESTER PROJECTS. THEY WILL THEN TAKE ADVANTAGE OF THEIR EXPERTISE IN RESEARCH AND EXTENSION RELATING TO ANAEROBIC DIGESTION (AD) TO INTERVIEW POTENTIAL AD PARTNERS, WITH THE GOAL OF EXPLORING THEIR INTEREST IN AD PROJECTS, THE POTENTIAL BENEFITS AND PERCEIVED CONSTRAINTS THAT WOULD AFFECT THEIR PARTICIPATION IN A PROJECT, AND THEIR PARTICULAR INDUSTRY'S RISKS AND RISK THRESHOLDS. WSU WILL THEN PRODUCE TAILORED RESEARCH BRIEFS TO ADDRESS CONCERNS SPECIFIC TO EACH GROUP OF STAKEHOLDERS AND BRING THE MOST APPROPRIATE AND WILLING STAKEHOLDERS TOGETHER IN PROJECT CHARRETTES TO LAY OUT TANGIBLE GROUNDWORK FOR VIABLE ANAEROBIC DIGESTER PROJECTS.

THIS AGREEMENT WILL FUND NORTH CENTRAL TEXAS COUNCIL OF GOVERNMENT, WHO WILL BE PARTNERING WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS AT ARLINGTON.  THEY WILL COORDINATE WITH STAKEHOLDERS IN THE NORTH CENTRAL TEXAS REGION TO COMPLETE THE NORTH CENTRAL TEXAS REGIONAL FOOD WASTE TO FUEL FEASIBILITY STUDY. THE FEASIBILITY STUDY WILL ADDRESS NUMEROUS CHALLENGES TO THE OVERALL SUSTAINABILITY OF THE NORTH CENTRAL TEXAS REGION, INCLUDING THE RETENTION AND IMPROVEMENT OF LANDFILL CAPACITY, DIVERSION OF FOOD WASTE AND OTHER ORGANICS, IMPROVEMENT TO BIOSOLID MANAGEMENT, PRODUCTION OF BIOGAS AND RENEWABLE FLEET FUEL, REDUCTION OF GREENHOUSE GAS AND OTHER EMISSIONS, AND THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A REPLICABLE REGIONAL MODEL. ENGAGEMENT OF STAKEHOLDERS DURING KICK-OFF AND FINAL WORKSHOPS WILL BE USED TO GUIDE THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE FEASIBILITY STUDY. THE FEASIBILITY STUDY WILL ADDRESS THE SUPPLY AND COLLECTION OF ORGANICS, DEMAND FOR RENEWABLE NATURAL GAS (RNG) VEHICLES, LOCATIONS FOR ANAEROBIC DIGESTION, AND THE COSTS/BENEFITS OF IMPLEMENTATION. IT ADDRESSES EPA GOALS OF IMPROVED AIR QUALITY, LAND REVITALIZATION, AND CONTAMINATION PREVENTION, ALONG WITH EPA DESIRE TO INCREASE UTILIZATION OF ANAEROBIC DIGESTION TECHNOLOGY, BY ADVANCING THE DEPLOYMENT OF ANAEROBIC DIGESTION AND EVALUATING THE DEMAND FOR FUTURE DIESEL TO RENEWABLE NATURAL GAS (RNG) FLEET TECHNICIANS.

THIS ACTION APPROVES AN AWARD IN THE AMOUNT OF $25,000 TO SOCIETY OF SAINT ANDREW FOR A PILOT PROJECT TO REDUCE SURPLUS FARM FOOD LOSS IN,BY GATHERING FIELD ON-FARM SAMPLING DATA AND OTHER COMPONENTS OF THE FOOD SYSTEM TO APPLY TO AN INTERACTIVE MAP OF TENESSEE TO BETTER UNDERSTAND ON FARM SURPLUS FOOD LOSS THAT WILL ENABLE ASSISTANCE AND PILOT STRATEGIES TO REDUCE THESE LOSSES.

THIS ACTION APPROVES AN AWARD IN THE AMOUNT OF $25,000 TO FOOD RECOVERY NETWORK, INC TO SUPPORT THEIR PILOT PROGRAM TO REDUCE FARM FOOD LOSS AND EXPAND ACCESS AND AVAILABILITY OF SURPLUS LOCAL FOOD FOR ATLANTA COMMUNITIES IN LOW ACCESS AND LOW INCOME AREAS.

DESCRIPTION:THE CHIPPEWA CREE TRIBAL WATER RESOURCES DEPARTMENT (TWRD) LOOKS TO DEVELOP A SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM DESIGNED TO MEET THE UNIQUE NEEDS OF THE COMMUNITY. CREATING A SYSTEM THAT IS AFFORDABLE, SAFE, HEALTHY, AND SUSTAINABLE FOR ALL COMMUNITY MEMBERS. BUILDING A PROGRAM FROM THE GROUND UP, BASED ON THE UNIQUE NEEDS OF THE COMMUNITY, INCREASE SUCCESS AND SUSTAINABILITY IN THE LONG RUN. THE NEED FOR EDUCATION AND OUTREACH, STAFF, TRAINING, MORE EFFICIENT PLANNING, AND EMPHASIS ON CREATING A CIRCULAR ECONOMY VIA INCREASED RECYCLING EFFORTS, WILL LEND TO THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM BASED ON THE FOLLOWING OVERALL GOAL: TO CONDUCT ACTIVITIES THAT BUILD CAPACITY, IMPROVE MANAGEMENT OF SOLID WASTE, AND EDUCATE THE COMMUNITY. BY DOING THIS WE WILL CREATE A SELF-SUSTAINING SOLID WASTE PROGRAM, PROTECTING COMMUNITY HEALTH AND INCREASE SAFETY AND PROTECTION OF THE ENVIRONMENT.

ACTIVITIES:MILESTONE 1: 
CONDUCT WASTE COMPOSITION STUDY BY PHYSICALLY SORTING RANDOM SAMPLES OF WASTE FROM SELECT SITES, TO IDENTIFY AND CHARACTERIZE SOLID WASTE GENERATION AND CONDUCT WASTE
COMPOSITION ANALYSIS. 
FINDINGS WILL BE USED TO: (TYPE OF PROJECT- SECTION I (C).1. A AND B)
ACTIVITIES: (IMPLEMENTED THROUGHOUT 12-MONTH PROJECT PERIOD)
- INFORM EDUCATION AND OUTREACH PROGRAMS
- DETERMINE THE CONTENT OF VARIOUS WASTE AND TARGET SELECT MATERIALS FOR RECYCLING
- CONDUCT (1) COMMUNITY SURVEY TO DETERMINE TYPE OF RECYCLING PROGRAM NEEDED 
- DEVELOP (1) SUMMARY REPORT AND RECOMMENDATIONS FOR A COMMUNITY RECYCLING PROGRAM
- BETTER UNDERSTAND THE CONTENT OF ILLEGAL DUMP PRIOR TO CLEAN UP EFFORTS

MILESTONE 2: 
CONDUCT EDUCATION AND OUTREACH ON PROPER DISPOSAL AND WASTE REDUCTION ACTIVITIES AND TRAIN STAFF ON PROPER DISPOSAL AND WASTE REDUCTION. 
FINDINGS WILL BE USED TO: (TYPE OF PROJECT- SECTION (C).3 A)
ACTIVITIES: (IMPLEMENTED THROUGHOUT 12-MONTH PROJECT PERIOD)
- DEVELOP OUTREACH DOCUMENTS AND OTHER RESOURCE MATERIALS FOR TRIBAL LEADERS, COMMUNITY MEMBERS, BUSINESSES, AND LOCAL ORGANIZATIONS/PROGRAMS
- CREATE SIGNAGE THAT WILL ENHANCE ENFORCEMENT 
- DEVELOP A REWARD SYSTEM THAT WILL ENCOURAGE AND ENFORCE PROPER DISPOSAL AND WASTE REDUCTION. (1) COMMUNITY QUESTIONNAIRE WILL BE CONDUCTED TO ANALYZE/UNDERSTAND NEEDS,
INCREASE ENGAGEMENT, AND HELP DETERMINE TYPE OF REWARD SYSTEM.
- UTILIZE LOCAL RADIO PSA'S AND CREATE PARTNERSHIPS WITH LOCAL PROGRAMS/ORGANIZATIONS
- DEVELOP A SOCIAL MEDIA CAMPAIGN, UTILIZING FACEBOOK, INSTAGRAM, AND LOCAL WEBSITES TO COMMUNICATE MONTHLY MESSAGES THAT ARE DEVELOPED TO DRAW ATTENTION TO WASTE MATTERS
- TRAINING FOR STAFF BY COLLABORATING WITH OTHER TRIBAL COMMUNITIES THAT HAVE IMPLEMENTED A SUCCESSFUL SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM 

MILESTONE 3: 
UPDATE INTEGRATED WASTE MANAGEMENT PLAN (IWMP). 
FINDINGS WILL BE USED TO: (TYPE OF PROJECT- SECT I (C).4 A)
ACTIVITIES: (IMPLEMENTED THROUGHOUT 12-MONTH PROJECT PERIOD)
- UPDATE ELEMENT(S) WITHIN EXISTING IWMP THAT ACCOUNTS FOR A POPULATION INCREASE, AND CHANGES IN COMMUNITY NEEDS AND PROJECTED FUTURE OPERATIONS. INCLUDED IN IWMP WILL BE THE CREATION OF A RURAL RECYCLING PROGRAM THAT SUPPORTS A CIRCULAR ECONOMY. 
- OFFICIAL APPROVAL OF IWMP
- MONTHLY MEETINGS WITH COOPERATIVE PARTNERS: BUSINESS COMMITTEE, CCT EPA, TERAC, CCT PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT
- COMMUNITY MEETINGS FOR INPUT ON RECYCLE, REWARDS, AND IWMP

MILESTONE 4: 
HIRE (1) SITE MONITOR TO OVERSEE AND ENFORCE SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT CAPACITY. 
FINDINGS WILL BE USED TO: (TYPE OF PROJECT- SECTION I (C).5 A AND 7 A)
ACTIVITIES: CCT HUMAN RESOURCES TO ADVERTISE MONITOR POSITION
- CCT BUSINESS COMMITTEE WILL HIRE MONITOR 
- MONITOR WILL 
  - ENFORCE LANDFILL POLICIES AND PROCEDURES
  - DIRECT AND/OR ASSIST COMMUNITY ON PROPER DISPOSAL 
  - DISTRIBUTE FLIERS AND PAMPHLETS REGARDING PROPER DISPOSAL AND RECYCLING
  - MONITOR ALL SOLID WASTE AND RECYCLING, ENSURI
THIS PARTIAL AWARD FUNDS ONLY ODEQ ADMINISTRATIVE ACTIVITIES.  THE TOTAL AWARD WILL FUND REMEDIAL DESIGN ACTIVITIES PERFORMED BY ODEQ AT THE OKLAHOMA

DESCRIPTION:THE FOREST COUNTY POTAWATOMI COMMUNITY (FCPC) SOLID WASTE PROGRAM ANALYSIS AND PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT PROJECT AIMS TO PROTECT THE ENVIRONMENT AND COMMUNITY HEALTH BY PRACTICING AND PROMOTING IMPROVED SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES, AND BY SHARING RESOURCES WITH OTHER TRIBES AND COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS. THE FOREST COUNTY POTAWATOMI COMMUNITY AND PARTNERING ENTITIES WILL ACHIEVE THESE GOALS THROUGH: (A) WASTE SITE VISITS AND ANALYSIS (B) WASTE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM EVALUATIONS (C) SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT PLAN DEVELOPMENT (D) PUBLIC OUTREACH AND (E) INTERNAL ENVIRONMENTAL ADVOCACY. FCPC IS CONFIDENT THAT THIS PROJECT WILL LAY THE FOUNDATION FOR AN EFFECTIVE SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM, THE REMOVAL AND REDUCTION OF OPEN DUMP SITES, INCREASED PUBLIC AWARENESS AND PARTICIPATION, AND THE AUGMENTATION OF INTERTRIBAL COLLABORATION. ACTIVITIES:THE FOREST COUNTY POTAWATOMI COMMUNITY AND PARTNERING ENTITIES WILL ACHIEVE WORKPLAN GOALS THROUGH: (A) WASTE SITE VISITS AND ANALYSIS (B) WASTE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM EVALUATIONS (C) SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT PLAN DEVELOPMENT (D) PUBLIC OUTREACH AND (E) INTERNAL ENVIRONMENTAL ADVOCACY. FCPC IS CONFIDENT THAT THIS PROJECT WILL LAY THE FOUNDATION FOR AN EFFECTIVE SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM, THE REMOVAL AND REDUCTION OF OPEN DUMP SITES, INCREASED PUBLIC AWARENESS AND PARTICIPATION, AND THE AUGMENTATION OF INTERTRIBAL COLLABORATION. SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:FCPC IS CONFIDENT THAT THIS PROJECT WILL LAY THE FOUNDATION FOR AN EFFECTIVE SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM, THE REMOVAL AND REDUCTION OF OPEN DUMP SITES, INCREASED PUBLIC AWARENESS AND PARTICIPATION, AND THE AUGMENTATION OF INTERTRIBAL COLLABORATION. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES WILL INCLUDE THE FOREST COUNTY POTAWATOMI COMMUNITY RESIDENTS, PARTNERING TRIBAL COMMUNITIES,  AND TO THE STATE OF WISCONSIN AT LARGE.

DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT WILL QUANTIFY THE AMOUNT OF ORGANIC WASTE DIVERSION RESULTING FROM THE INSTALLATION OF AN ANAEROBIC DIGESTION (AD) SYSTEM THAT IS OPTIMIZED FOR BREWERY WASTE, AS WELL AS CONSUMER FOOD WASTE FROM A BREWPUB RESTAURANT. THEY WILL MEASURE THE AMOUNT OF BREWERY AND FOOD WASTES FROM THE OPERATION, AND WILL USE DATA FOR THE WASTE STREAMS DIVERTED TO ESTIMATE BIOGAS FROM CO-DIGESTION OF FOOD WASTE AND BREWERY WASTEWATERS USING A MODEL SYSTEM.ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP THE CAPACITY FOR ANAEROBIC DIGESTION (AD) OF FOOD AND BREWERY WASTE BY QUANTIFYING THE POTENTIAL FOR WASTE DIVERSION AT MICROBREWERY-BREWPUB BUSINESSES, ESTIMATING BIOGAS AND FERTILIZER YIELD FROM AN AD SYSTEM OPTIMIZED FOR THIS SCALE OF OPERATION, AND DEMONSTRATING THE OPPORTUNITY FOR SMALL-SCALE AD WITH A PROTOTYPE SYSTEM TO REGIONAL NETWORKS.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:THE ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE: QUANTIFYING AND SUMMARIZING THE VOLUME OF THE COMPOSITION OF FOOD AND BREWERY WASTE TO BE DIVERTED, INCREASING BUSINESS AND IMPROVING PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING OF ANAEROBIC DIGESTION (AD) OPPORTUNITIES THROUGH A PILOT-SCALE AD SYSTEM, AND DEVELOPING A SMALL-SCALE AD SYSTEM DESIGNED TO IMPROVE THE CAPACITY OF MICROBREWERIES TO PROCESS FOOD AND SPENT-GRAIN WASTE. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT ARE THE BUSINESSES AND COMMUNITIES OF OHIO.

IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE STATUTORY AUTHORITY DELEGATED TO EPA UNDER THE RESOURCE CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY ACT (RCRA), THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL ADDRESS U.S. EPA REGION 5'S PRIORITY TO DEVELOP A BLOCKCHAIN TRACKING SYSTEM AND DEMONSTRATE ITS EFFICACY IN LAKE COUNTY, IL WITH THE HELP OF THE SOLID WASTE AGENCY OF LAKE COUNTY (SWALCO). DURING THIS PROJECT UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS, CHICAGO (UIC) WILL EXPLORE HOW BLOCKCHAIN PLATFORMS CAN REDUCE THE COSTS ASSOCIATED WITH RECYCLING PLASTIC MATERIALS (HDPE AND PET) AND ADDITIONAL MATERIALS ARRIVING AT RECYCLING FACILITIES IN LAKE COUNTY. INPUTS INTO THE PLATFORM INCLUDE DATA REGARDING COLLECTION AND TRANSPORTATION, CLEANING AND SORTING, PROCESSING, LOGISTICS, SALES AND MARKETING, BUSINESS PRACTICES, AND LEGAL REQUIREMENTS. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN A TRACKING SYSTEM FOR MATERIALS KNOWN AS BLOCK CHAIN ENVIRONMENTAL ASSET TRACKING SYSTEM (BEATS) THAT CAN BE UTILIZED BY SWALCO AND A FINAL REGIONAL WORKSHOP ON THE PROJECT AND THE MAJOR ACTIVITI

IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE STATUTORY AUTHORITY DELEGATED TO EPA UNDER THE RESOURCE CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY ACT (RCRA), THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL ADDRESS U.S. EPA REGION 5&RSQUOANDS PRIORITY OF WASTED FOOD SOLUTIONS FOR OHIO PHASE II TO DEVELOP AND BUILD ON RESOURCES THAT SUPPORT WASTED FOOD DIVERSION. DURING PHASE 1, CET AND PARTNERS IDENTIFIED A NEED FOR A RESOURCE TO INCENTIVIZE PREVENTION. ADDITIONALLY, FOLLOWING THIS WORK, CET RECEIVED SEVERAL REQUESTS FROM COMMUNITIES OUTSIDE THE SOUTHWEST OHIO REGION, THE TARGET GEOGRAPHY FOR PHASE1, FOR RESOURCES FOCUSED ON WASTED FOOD REDUCTION, RECOVERY, AND DIVERSION. PHASE II WILL ADDRESS THESE GAPS. CET WILL CAPITALIZE ON OUR NATIONAL EXPERIENCE WITH BUSINESSES WHOSE CORE OPERATIONS DO NOT FOCUS ON WASTED FOOD DIVERSION, TO CURATE RESOURCES THAT ELEVATE THE PROFILE OF, AND AWARENESS FOR, WASTE REDUCTION AND RECOVERY IN OHIO. DESCRIPTION:
IN 2019, VERMONT IMPLEMENTED A BAN ON LANDFILLING FOOD WASTE. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO EVALUATE THE OPTION TO DIVERT FOOD WASTE FROM LANDFILLS TO EXISTING ANAEROBIC DIGESTION (AD) CAPACITY AT FARM DIGESTERS, WHICH COULD ENABLE VERMONT FARMERS TO PRODUCE ADDITIONAL BIOGAS AND ELECTRICITY AND INCREASE THEIR INCOME. HOWEVER, FOOD WASTE ALSO IMPACTS RESIDUALS (DIGESTATE) FROM ANAEROBIC DIGESTION THAT NEED TO BE MANAGED, INCLUDING NUTRIENTS AND PLASTICS. THIS STUDY, WILL ASSESS (1) CURRENT CAPACITY AT ON-FARM DIGESTERS TO ACCEPT FOOD WASTES; (2) POTENTIAL IMPACTS OF FOOD WASTE CO-DIGESTION ON BIOGAS PRODUCTION; AND (3) POTENTIAL IMPACTS OF CO-DIGESTION ON NUTRIENTS AND MICROPLASTICS IN DIGESTATE.
ACTIVITIES:
 1: INVENTORY EXISTING ON-FARM DIGESTER CAPACITY AND ASSESS FARMER WILLINGNESS TO ACCEPT FOOD WASTE.
 2: CONFIRM STABLE BIOGAS PRODUCTION DURING FOOD WASTE CO-DIGESTION WITH MULTIPLE ON-FARM DIGESTER MICROBIAL COMMUNITIES.
 3: QUANTIFY THE IMPACTS OF FOOD WASTE USE IN AD ON NUTRIENT CYCLING AND MICROPLASTICS FATE.
OUTCOMES:
DELIVERABLES'
1) INVENTORY OF ON-FARM DIGESTERS
2) BIOMETHANE POTENTIAL TESTS INCLUDING DIGESTATES AND MANURE/FOOD WASTE RATIOS
3) RESIDUALS ANALYSIS INCLUDING NUTRIENTS AND RESIDUAL PLASTICS

OUTCOMES AND INTENDED BENEFICIARY: 
1: INCREASED PUBLIC AND/OR BUSINESS UNDERSTANDING OF AD OPPORTUNITIES AND BENEFITS. THIS OUTCOME WILL BE MEASURED BASED ON THE NUMBER OF PARTICIPANTS AT THE
STAKEHOLDER MEETING AND ENGAGEMENT BASED ON NUMBER OF QUESTIONS ASKED. PROVIDE CRITICAL INFORMATION TO FARMERS RELATED TO BIOGAS PRODUCTION, MICROPLASTICS, AND NUTRIENTS WILL ALLEVIATE HESITANCY FOR ACCEPTING FOOD WASTES.
 2: POTENTIAL INCREASED ENERGY PRODUCED THROUGH ANAEROBIC DIGESTION (BTU YR-1). THE HEAT VALUE OF BIOGAS GENERATED FROM CO-DIGESTION OF FOOD WASTE WILL BE ESTIMATED BASED ON THE TOTAL BIOGAS PRODUCTION DURING BMP TESTS AND THE METHANE CONTENT OF THE BIOGAS.ANTICIPATE THAT 1 TRILLION BTU YR-1 CAN BE RECOVERED BY CO-DIGESTION OF FOOD WASTE AT EXISTING ON-FARM ANAEROBIC DIGESTERS. DETERMINE THE BTU YR-1 THAT CAN BE PRODUCED IF ADDITIONAL ANAEROBIC DIGESTERS ARE CONSTRUCTED TO MEET A NEED FOR ADDITIONAL DIGESTER CAPACITY. PROVIDE CRITICAL INFORMATION TO FARMERS RELATED TO BIOGAS PRODUCTION, MICROPLASTICS, AND NUTRIENTS WILL ALLEVIATE HESITANCY FOR ACCEPTING FOOD WASTES.
-3: POTENTIAL DOLLARS EARNED BY FARMERS ACCEPTING FOOD WASTE ($ LB-1 FOOD WASTE). THE DOLLARS EARNED WILL BE A RESULT OF INCREASED ELECTRICITY PRODUCTION THROUGH BIOGAS COMBUSTION. CONVERT BIOGAS PRODUCTION TO A MONETARY AMOUNT BASED ON ASSUMED GENERATION EFFICIENCY AND CURRENT PRICING SCHEMES FOR ELECTRICITY PURCHASES. CONSIDER TIPPING FEES (I.E., COSTS PAID BY A SOLID WASTE MANAGER TO DROP OF WASTES AT A DIGESTER) AS AN ADDITIONAL SOURCE OF INCOME.

IN TOTAL, THIS WORK WILL INFORM FARMERS AND SOLID WASTE MANAGERS ON BARRIERS TO FOOD WASTE CO-DIGESTION AND SUGGEST STRATEGIES TO OVERCOME THESE BARRIERS.
SUBRECIPIENT:
NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.

PER YOUR APPLICATION REQUEST DATED JULY 13, 2020 THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS BEING AWARDED FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $290,422 TO THE CENTER FOR ECO TECHNOLOGY (CET) PROPOSES THE NORTHEAST ANAEROBIC DIGESTION ACCELERATOR (NADA) TO INCREASE THE USE OF AD FOR PROCESSING AND RECOVERING VALUE FROM WASTED FOOD. NADA IS A COLLABORATION AMONG CET AND AD FACILITIES, ENVIRONMENTAL AGENCIES IN EACH PARTNER STATE, OTHER GOVERNMENT UNITS, COMMUNITY GROUPS, NON-PROFITS, BUSINESSES THAT GENERATE WASTED FOOD SUITABLE FOR AD, AND OTHER SERVICE PROVIDERS (HAULERS, DEPACKAGING FACILITIES) IN MA, CT, RI, NY, NJ, PA (PHILADELPHIA), AND MD, ALL GEOGRAPHIES WITH FOOD WASTE DISPOSAL POLICIES OR TARGETS AND EXISTING OR PLANNED AD INFRASTRUCTURE. THE NORTHEAST IS THE LEADING U.S. REGION FOR ADVANCED WASTED FOOD POLICY AND REGULATIONS. NADA WILL LEVERAGE THIS UNIQUE LANDSCAPE TO AMPLIFY THE IMPACTS OF ANY ONE STATE ACTING ALONE BY FACILITATING INFORMATION AND KNOWLEDGE EXCHANGE, AND ACCELERATING THE GROWTH OF WASTED FOOD DIGESTION AND INTER-STATE SERVICE PROVIDER ACTIVITY. OUR THREE-PRONGED APPROACH TO BOLSTERING FOOD WASTE DIVERSION TO AD INCLUDES: 1) PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE (TA) TO INCREASE FOOD SCRAP DIVERSION TO AD; 2) TRAINING AND CAPACITY BUILDING FOR STAKEHOLDERS ACROSS THE WASTED FOOD MARKETPLACE TO STRENGTHEN AND EXPAND AD ACTIVITY; AND 3) DEVELOPING AND DISSEMINATING RESOURCES TO ASSIST IN STAKEHOLDER OUTREACH, EDUCATION, AND TRAINING ACROSS THE MARKETPLACE. THIS WORK DIRECTLY SUPPORTS THE OBJECTIVES IN THE RFA AND CONTRIBUTES TO EPA'S SUSTAINABLE MATERIALS MANAGEMENT GOAL, DEMONSTRATING TRANSFERRABLE APPROACHES TO INCREASING AD UTILIZATION AND GENERATION OF USEFUL PRODUCTS FROM FOOD WASTE, AND FURTHERS EPA'S STRATEGIC PLAN GOALS TO DIVERT FOOD WASTE FROM LANDFILLS/INCINERATION, THUS PROTECTING AIR, LAND, AND WATER QUALITY, AND ENHANCING SHARED ACCOUNTABILITY.
